page.title: Organisation for the Maintenance of Supplies

revision.text:
The '''Organisation for the Maintenance of Supplies''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[right-wing]] movement, established in 1925 to provide volunteers in the event of a [[general strike]]. During the [[General Strike of 1926]], it was taken over by the government to provide vital services, such as transport and communications.
==Prelude== On "[[Red Friday]]", 31 July 1925, the government avoided a confrontation with the [[Miners Federation of Great Britain]], which was expected to be followed by secondary [[industrial action]] by the railwaymen of the [[National Union of Railwaymen]], and wider confrontation. However, as [[Stanley Baldwin]] said later, "we were not ready". The government had an emergency plan but inadequate means of implementing it. It thus established a [[Royal Commission]] and provided a subsidy to enable the mineowners to maintain the miners' existing wages and hours of work.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |pp= 122–7}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Mason |1969 |p= 7}}</ref>
In early August, [[Home Secretary]] [[William Joynson-Hicks, 1st Viscount Brentford|William Joynson-Hicks]] reported to the cabinet on the state of preparations, and his recommendations were approved, but the establishment of a volunteer service was deferred.<ref>{{harvnb|Phillips | 1976|p= 95}} </ref>
==Formation== The OMS had its public origins in the letters page of ''[[The Times]]'', where many were calling for the formation of a volunteer organisation to take over the jobs of striking workers, in the event of a [[general strike]], which was widely feared by the [[conservatism|conservative]] establishment at the time, as part of a '[[communism|communist]] plot'. The same page was used on 25 September 1925 by the Home Secretary to announce the formation of just such a group, the new OMS.<ref name="Perkins70">{{harvnb|Perkins| 2006| p= 70}}</ref> Nevertheless, he admitted, on 1 October, that he had known of its inauguration for many weeks and that its promoters had consulted him. The government had no objection to it.<ref>{{harvnb|Page Arnot |1926 |p= 54}} </ref>
The organisation, to be run by a committee chaired by [[Charles Hardinge, 1st Baron Hardinge of Penshurst|Lord Hardinge]], was to have branches in every city and to recruit volunteers in five classes, four of which were based on the men's fitness and age. The fifth was for women, who were to be set to work only where they could avoid any "rough handling".<ref name="Perkins70"/> [[John Jellicoe, 1st Earl Jellicoe|Lord Jellicoe]] and other top military men sat on the committee, to give the OMS a military discipline and to instill public confidence in the group that such important figures were involved.<ref name="Renshaw130">{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975|pp= 130–131}}</ref>
The organisation was, however, explicitly non-political. [[British Fascists]] were barred from joining unless they changed their name, abandoned their military structure and changed their manifesto. That led to a split in the British Fascists, with several leaders leaving to become the ''loyalists'', an organisation that would be absorbed into OMS.<ref>{{harvnb|Benewick |1969 |p= 35}}</ref> Still, it showed apparent independence by employing nobody in government service.<ref name="Renshaw130"/>
==Reaction== Whilst the scheme was enthusiastically supported by the right-wing ''[[Daily Mail]]'' it was denounced as a form of [[fascism]] not only by the [[Communist Party of Great Britain]] but also by the [[anti-communist]] ''[[Daily Express]]'', which compared the OMS to the [[Ku Klux Klan]] and the [[Blackshirts]].<ref>{{harvnb|Perkins|1971|pp= 70–71}}</ref> An early speech by one of the group's leaders was deemed unfit for broadcast by the [[BBC]], which feared that it would compromise their impartiality.<ref name="Perkins71">{{harvnb|Perkins|1971|p= 71}}</ref>
Brigadier-General [[William Horwood (police commissioner)|William Horwood]], the [[Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police]] also refused to work with what he believed to be a fascist organisation, and by the end of 1925 the government had informed General Sir Robert McCalmont that in the event of any general strike, the OMS would be disbanded and its membership taken over entirely by the government.<ref name="Perkins71"/>
Still, the OMS had the confidence of some provincial police forces and branches of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] despite its inauspicious start.<ref name="Perkins71"/>
==Development== The development of OMS was not regarded as wholly favourable by some government officials, who were concerned at rumours that OMS agents were expecting to supplant official organisations in the event of an emergency.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw|1975|pp=132–3}}</ref> The junior ministers [[William Mitchell-Thomson, 1st Baron Selsdon|William Mitchell-Thomson]] and [[John Davidson, 1st Viscount Davidson|J.C.C. Davidson]] met the leaders of OMS, who agreed not to establish branches where there were local objections, but to encourage unofficial contacts between the local officials. OMS would concentrate on recruiting lorry drivers rather than those more likely to be employed by local authorities.<ref>{{harvnb|Phillips |1976 |pp= 96–7}} </ref>
OMS was short of funds by March 1926, having failed to gain the commercial backing that it hoped.<ref>{{harvnb|Phillips |1976 |p= 97}} </ref> It also lacked the means to train volunteers.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |p=186 }} </ref>
==General Strike== Following the outbreak of the strike and the introduction by the government of emergency powers, it turned over its membership lists to the new government civil commissioners and so became a state organisation.<ref>{{harvnb|Perkins|1971|p= 114}}</ref> Although the OMS name continued to be used, any notion of independence was abandoned, and it became an arm of government.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw|1975| p= 131}}</ref> The group had some 100,000 members registered at the commencement of the strike, but the middle class of many of its volunteers meant that they often proved wholly unsuited to the manual work, such as the running railways and ports.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw|1975|pp= 132–133}}</ref>
It produced slightly over 5000 volunteers. Car drivers, lorry drivers and power station workers were the largest groups.<ref>{{harvnb|Phillips | 1975|p= 134}}</ref>
It managed to produce the ''[[British Gazette]]'', a pro-government newspaper, during the strike.<ref>[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/cabinetpapers/help/glossary-o.htm The Cabinet Papers Glossary - O] from [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] website</ref>
==Fascism== The [[British Fascisti]] (BF), which maintained transport and communications units to be used in the event of a strike, provided an organisational structure for the OMS, but there was uncertainty at government level about allowing BF members to join the OMS given fears about their potentially revolutionary nature.<ref>Dorril, p. 198</ref> Members of the BF were allowed to join only if it agreed to renounce fascism and the BF name, which wss rejected by the majority of the group's controlling committee, under [[Rotha Lintorn-Orman]]. The minority faction, led by Brigadier-General [[R.B.D. Blakeney]] and Rear-Admiral A.E. Armstrong, split to form a new group known as the Loyalists (as well as the Scottish Loyalists under the [[Patrick James Boyle, 8th Earl of Glasgow|Earl of Glasgow]]), which was subsumed into the OMS as soon as the strike began.<ref>{{harvnb|Benewick|1969|p= 35}}</ref>
Still, individual fascists obtained high rank within the OMS. BF member and later co-founder of the [[National Fascisti]] Colonel Ralph Bingham worked along with [[Peter Howard (journalist)|Peter Howard]], who had published a magazine for fascists in [[Ukraine]] and would later be a member of the [[New Party (United Kingdom)|New Party]]. They ran an OMS depot during the strike.<ref>Dorril, p. 184</ref> The BF's [[Neil Francis Hawkins]], later a leading figure within both the [[British Union of Fascists]] and the [[Union Movement]], was also important in the OMS during the strike.<ref>Dorril, p. 200</ref>
==Later organisations== The OMS can in some ways be compared to 1970s movements such as [[Civil Assistance]], which played on widespread public fear of trade union militancy.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}}
==Sources== * R. Page Arnet, ''The General Strike, May 1926: its origins and history'', Labour Research Department, 1926; reprint 1967 * Robert Benewick, ''A study of British fascism: Political Violence and Public Order'', Allan Lane, 1969 * Stephen Dorril, ''Blackshirt: Sir Oswald Mosley & British Fascism'', Penguin Books, 2007 * A. Mason, 'The Government and the General Strike, 1926', ''International Review of Social History 14 (1969), pp. 1-22 * Anne Perkins, ''A Very British Strike: 3 May - 12 May 1926'', Macmillan, 2006 * G.A. Phillips, ''The General Strike: the politics of industrial conflict'', Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1976 * Patrick Renshaw, ''The General Strike'', Taylor & Francis, 1975

{{Refimprove|date=August 2018}} {{Italic title}} [[Image:posthuman future.jpg|thumb|200px|''Our Posthuman Future'' cover]] '''''Our Posthuman Future: Consequences of the Biotechnology Revolution''''' is a 2002 book by [[Francis Fukuyama]]. In it, he discusses the potential threat to [[liberal democracy]] that use of new and emerging [[biotechnologies]] for [[transhumanist]] ends poses.{{cite journal|author=Kazin, Michael|authorlink=Michael Kazin|title=Review of ''Our Posthuman Future''|journal=Perspectives in Biology and Medicine|volume=47|issue=1|date=Winter 2004|pages=151–152|doi=10.1353/pbm.2004.0012}}{{cite newspaper|newspaper=The Guardian|date=31 May 2002|title=Review of ''Our Posthuman Future''|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2002/jun/01/highereducation}} From the back cover of the paperback edition:
A decade after his now-famous pronouncement of "the [[end of history]]", Francis Fukuyama argues that as a result of biomedical advances, we are facing the possibility of a future in which our humanity itself will be altered beyond recognition. Fukuyama sketches a brief history of man's changing understanding of human nature: from Plato and Aristotle's belief that humans had "natural ends" to the ideals of utopians and dictators of the modern age who sought to remake mankind for ideological ends. Fukuyama argues that the ability to manipulate the DNA of all of one person's descendants will have profound, and potentially terrible, consequences for our political order, even if undertaken with the best of intentions.
== Human Nature == Fukuyama defines human nature as "the sum of the behavior and characteristics that are typical of the human species, arising from genetics rather than environmental factors."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=130|oclc=49502279}} The "typicality" is further defined as a statistical phenomenon of the usual distribution of measured parameters describing human characteristics, such the [[normal distribution]] of height or [[Intelligence quotient|intellectual quotient]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=130–138|oclc=49502279}} The author recognizes that distinguishing "pathological" from "normal" is difficult, but insists that drawing the line between the two is not only possible, but is routinely achieved by regulatory agencies through a legislative process.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=209–210|oclc=49502279}} "It has often seemed to me that the only people who can argue that there is no difference in principle between disease and health are those who have never been sick: if you have a virus or fracture your leg, you know perfectly well that something is wrong."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=209|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=|oclc=49502279}} == Human Dignity == Possession of moral choice, human language, reason, sociability, emotions, sentience, and consciousness constitute distinguishing qualities that differentiate humans from animals. Fukuyama refers to the irreducible totality of these qualities as "Factor X", "the complex whole" as opposed to "the sum of simple parts", which forms the foundation of human dignity. Moreover, he believes that "every member of the human species possesses a genetic endowment that allows him or her to become a whole human being, an endowment that distinguishes a human in essence from other types of creatures." Thus, he squarely places the source of human dignity in human genetics providing the argument against unregulated modification of human germline cells.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=170–172|oclc=49502279}} Fukuyama argues that the moral status of human embryos is higher than that of human cells or human tissues because they possess "the potential to become a full human being."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=176|oclc=49502279}} He concludes that "it is therefore reasonable, on non-religious grounds, to question whether researchers should be free to create, clone, and destroy human embryos at will." == Human Rights == Francis Fukuyama argues that informed discussion of human rights requires understanding of human purposes, which themselves rest on a concept of human nature and human dignity. Therefore, biotechnology targeting human nature will inevitably affect the discourse of values and politics. He provides several arguments to defend his human nature-based theory of rights: # Classic philosophical accounts by Socrates and Plato argue for the existence of human nature. Fukuyama believes that these classic accounts are too easily dismissed by "thoughtless contemporary commentators [who] sneer at Plato's "simplistic" psychology".{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=118|oclc=49502279}} # The Fallacy of "Naturalistic Fallacy". In response to the assertion that moral obligations cannot be derived from the observation of natural world ("naturalistic fallacy"), Fukuyama demonstrates that humans routinely use emotions to prioritize values. For example, the fear of violent death produces the basic right of life, which some will consider a value higher than the freedom of religion. # Inconsistencies in the views of libertarian legal theorists, John Rawls and Ronald Dworkin. For example, Fukuyama shows that John Rawls in "[[A Theory of Justice]]", appeals to apparent observations of human nature, such as genetically programmed social reciprocity.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=121|oclc=49502279}} Ronald Dworkin, on the other hand, also appears to make assumptions about human nature: the existence of distinct natural human potential that can develop over time, efforts needed to cultivate this potential, and desirable choices of an individual regarding her potential. # Some decisions by the US Supreme Court "suggest priorities among the wide variety of human desires and purposes."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=123|oclc=49502279}} For example, Fukuyama suggests that the US Supreme Court decision [[Planned Parenthood v. Casey|Casey vs. Planned Parenthood]] defends "moral autonomy as the most important human right." # Values make collective action possible. "Human beings also find great satisfaction in the fact that values and norms are shared. Solipsistically held values defeat their own purpose and lead to a highly dysfunctional society in which people are unable to work together for common ends."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=125|oclc=49502279}} # Political history reveals the failure of political regimes which ignored the limits of human nature. For example, Fukuyama concludes that the ultimate failure of communism was caused by its "failure to respect the natural inclination to favor kin and private property."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=127|oclc=49502279}} == Political Control of Biotechnology == Fukuyama recognizes that translation of human nature into rights is difficult, but possible through a rational discussion of human ends. In his opinion, control of biotechnology is a political necessity. "Countries must regulate the development and use of technology politically, setting up institutions that will discriminate between those technological advances that promote human flourishing, and those that pose a threat to human dignity and well-being".{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=182|oclc=49502279}} He rejects the idea that "theology, philosophy, or politics" should not influence the scientific process, because "science by itself cannot establish the ends to which it is put." "Nazi doctors who injected concentration camp victims with infection agents... were in fact legitimate scientists who gathered real data that could potentially be put to good use."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=185|oclc=49502279}} Therefore, morality is needed to establish the end of science and the technology that science produces, and pronounce on whether those ends are good or bad." Political process that could decide on the legitimate uses of science is enabled by a democratically constituted political community acting through elected and scientifically informed representatives. Fukuyama rejects the notion that biotechnology cannot be controlled. Nuclear weapons, nuclear power, ballistic missiles, biological and chemical warfare, illegal human organ trade, neuropharmacological drugs, genetically modified foods, human experimentation have been the subject of effective international political control. Occasional breaking of the law, cannot be used as an excuse not to pursue legislature at all. "Every country makes murder a crime and attaches severe penalties to homicide, and yet murders nonetheless occur. The fact that they do has never been a reason for giving up on the law or on attempts to enforce it."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=189|oclc=49502279}} Author outlines several issues that need to be address to establish an effective international regulation of biotechnology:{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49502279|title=Our posthuman future : consequences of the biotechnology revolution|last=Francis.|first=Fukuyama,|date=2002|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|year=|isbn=0374236437|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=188–190|oclc=49502279}} # Over-regulation can create inefficiencies, drive up the business costs, and stifle innovation. # While most regulatory initiatives begin domestically, to be truly effective the regulation needs to be negotiated, harmonized, and enacted on the international level. # Risks, benefits, and enforcement costs of biotechnology need to clearly defined. # Different ethical views of biotechnology throughout the world. # Different political systems throughout the world. == Publication history == *Farrar Straus & Giroux, 2002, hardcover ({{ISBN|0-374-23643-7}}) *Picador USA, 2003, paperback ({{ISBN|0-312-42171-0}}). ==See also== *''[[The End of History and the Last Man]]'' *[[Transhumanism#Threats to morality and democracy|''Brave New World'' argument]] *''[[The Abolition of Man]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} {{Francis Fukuyama}} [[Category:2002 books]] [[Category:2002 in the environment]] [[Category:21st-century history books]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Transhumanist books]] [[Category:Works by Francis Fukuyama]] [[Category:History books about philosophy]] [[Category:History books about science]] [[Category:History books about medicine]] [[Category:History books about politics]] [[Category:Books about human rights]]

'''[[Law enforcement]]''' – subsystem of society that promotes adherence to the [[law]] by discovering and punishing persons who violate rules and [[norm (social)|norm]]s governing that society. Although the term may encompass entities such as [[court]]s and [[prison]]s, it most frequently applies to those who directly engage in patrols or surveillance to dissuade and discover [[crime|criminal]] activity, and those who investigate crimes and apprehend offenders.<ref name="ILE">Kären M. Hess, Christine Hess Orthmann, ''Introduction to Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice'' (2008), p. 1.</ref>

{{for|the defunct political party founded in 1985|Parti indépendantiste (1985)}} The '''Parti indépendantiste''' ('''PI''', in [[English language|English]]: Independence Party) was a [[political party]] promoting the [[Quebec independence|independence of Quebec]] from [[Canada]].
==History== The party was founded in 2007 by Éric Tremblay and Richard Gervais, in the aftermath of the [[Parti Québécois]]'s defeat in the [[Quebec general election, 2007|2007 Quebec election]]. It was registered as an official political party by the [[Chief Electoral Officer of Quebec]] on October 18, 2007.<ref>[http://www.electionsquebec.qc.ca/fr/ppc_liste_partis_candidats.asp?sect=prov#texte Elections Quebec]</ref> Candidates ran in three [[by-elections]] in [[Bourget (electoral district)|Bourget]], [[Hull (provincial electoral district)|Hull]], and [[Pointe-aux-Trembles]] held on May 12, 2008.<ref>[http://www.monvote.qc.ca/partielles/fr/ monvote.qc.ca]</ref><ref>[http://www.vigile.net/Le-Parti-independantiste-fera-ses Le Parti indépendantiste fera ses premières armes aux élections partielles, May 10, 2008]</ref> Party founder Richard Gervais, running in Bourget, received 376 votes (2.33%), finishing sixth out of six candidates.<ref>[http://www.electionsquebec.qc.ca/english/provincial/election-results/by-elections.php?e=5&s=1#s Official Results (Bourget, 2008), Le Directeur général des élections du Québec].</ref>
In the December [[Quebec general election, 2008|2008 provincial election]], the party nominated 19 candidates, who won a total of 4,227 votes, or 0.13% of the provincial total.
On November 24, 2011 at Université du Québec à Montréal, a debate between independentist parties included the [[Parti Québécois]], [[Quebec solidaire]] and [[Option nationale]], but excluded PI.<ref>http://www.vigile.net/Debat-sur-Les-strategies-et-modes</ref>
In the [[Quebec general election, 2012|2012 provincial election]], the party nominated ten candidates, who won a total of 1,244 votes, or 0.03% of the provincial total.
In the [[Quebec general election, 2014|2014 provincial election]], the party nominated one candidate, party leader Michel Lepage, who won 126 votes in Borduas riding.<ref>[http://resultats.dgeq.org/resultatsSommaires.en.html Directeur général des élections du Québec, April 9, 2014 Final 2:24 pm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409010704/http://resultats.dgeq.org/resultatsSommaires.en.html |date=April 9, 2014 }}</ref>
==Beliefs== According to former leader Éric Tremblay, the [[Parti Québécois]] has given up the will to actively seek the [[Quebec sovereignty movement|sovereignty of Quebec]]. Tremblay considers that, if given a majority of seats at the [[National Assembly of Quebec]], the Parti indépendantiste would have clear mandate to achieve sovereignty, even if it receives less than 50% of the popular vote. Tremblay did not hide his intention to put an end to all public financing of English-language schools and hospitals come his election, even though he would offer unilingual English-speakers health care in their language. The party suggests a reduction of more than half of the number of immigrants admitted, which would be reduced to 20,000, and the selection of immigrants based on the knowledge of French.<ref>http://www2.canoe.com/infos/quebeccanada/lequebecvote/archives/2008/11/20081118-162257.html</ref>
==Leadership and support== Éric Tremblay was the leader from 2008 to 2011, and the leader since 2011 has been Michel Lepage. According to the [[Chief Electoral Officer of Quebec]], donations were $33792 in 2008 and then fell sharply in 2009 and 2010. Prominent supporters have included:
* Author [[Victor-Lévy Beaulieu]], a disillusioned Parti Québécois supporter, voted for the [[Action démocratique du Québec]] (ADQ) in protest in the [[Quebec general election, 2007|2007 Quebec election]], but has become disappointed with the party. He announced on April 15, 2008 his intention to run for the Parti Indépendantiste in the district of [[Rivière-du-Loup (electoral district)|Rivière-du-Loup]] against ADQ leader [[Mario Dumont]].<ref>[http://www.radio-canada.ca/regions/est-quebec/2008/04/15/006-parti-independantiste_n.asp Radio-Canada 15 April 2008]</ref><ref>[http://www.vigile.net/Pourquoi-j-adhere-au-Parti Vigile.net] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080419235926/http://www.vigile.net/Pourquoi-j-adhere-au-Parti |date=2008-04-19 }}</ref> * Former Bloc Québécois [[House of Commons of Canada|Member of Parliament]] [[Ghislain Lebel]] announced on April 30, 2008 that he would be a Parti indépendantiste candidate. * Comedian Ghislain Taschereau left the party and became a member of the defunct [[Option nationale]] (ON) party.
===Links to neo-Nazis=== The Parti indépendantiste has been criticised for having links with [[neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]].<ref>Fachowatch [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120802080526/http://www.fachowatch.com/le-parti-independantiste-une-version-quebecoise-du-front-national-veritable-repere-de-fachos/ «Des néo-nazis dans les rangs et dans la hiérarchie du Parti Indépendantiste»]</ref> For example, a [[white power skinhead|neo-Nazi skinhead]] was the president of the executive committee for the region of Quebec<ref>Fachowatch [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120802080526/http://www.fachowatch.com/le-parti-independantiste-une-version-quebecoise-du-front-national-veritable-repere-de-fachos/ «Sébastien Moreau, un néo-nazi président du comité exécutif du Parti Indépendantiste»]</ref> and a member of the neo-Nazi group [[Blood & Honour]] is the treasurer.<ref>Fachowatch [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120802080526/http://www.fachowatch.com/le-parti-independantiste-une-version-quebecoise-du-front-national-veritable-repere-de-fachos/ «Un néo-nazi comme trésorier du Parti Indépendantiste»]</ref> The Parti Indépendantiste was present at a racist protest organized at Montreal in November 2011 with other well-known neo-Nazi groups.<ref>Fachowatch [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120802080526/http://www.fachowatch.com/le-parti-independantiste-une-version-quebecoise-du-front-national-veritable-repere-de-fachos/ «Organisation d'une manifestation raciste avec des néo-nazis à Montréal»]</ref> The party has been compared to the French [[National Front (France)|National Front]] because it recruited a fascist.<ref>La Tribu Du Verbe [https://archive.is/20120905190814/http://www.latribuduverbe.com/archives/2008/11/post_6.html «Le Parti Indépendantiste, une version Québécoise du Front National ?»] </ref> An article published in the newspaper ''Le Soleil'' accused the Parti Indépendantiste of being "authentic reactionary racist",<ref>Le Soleil [http://www.lapresse.ca/le-soleil/opinions/carrefour/201108/10/01-4424855-ultra-gauche-et-ultra-droite.php «Ultra-gauche et ultra-droite»]</ref> and another article by the same newspaper reported that a neo-Nazi was in the hierarchy of the party.<ref>Le Soleil [http://www.lapresse.ca/le-soleil/actualites/politique/201201/20/01-4487996-ex-administrateur-lie-au-neonazisme-le-parti-independantiste-inconfortable.php «Ex-administrateur lié au néonazisme : le Parti Indépendantiste inconfortable»]</ref>

{{refimprove|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox serial killer | name=Peter Stumpp | image= | caption=1589 tortured on the rack | birthname=Unknown | birth_date= | alias=The Werewolf of Bedburg | birth_place=Unknown | death_date=October 31, 1589 | cause=[[Capital punishment|Execution]] by [[breaking wheel|breaking]] | victims=18 | country=[[Holy Roman Empire]] | states=[[Electorate of Cologne]] | beginyear=c.1564 | endyear=1589 | apprehended=1589 | penalty=Death }}
'''Peter Stumpp''' (died 1589) (whose name is also spelled as '''Peter Stube''', '''Peter Stubbe''', '''Peter Stübbe''' or '''Peter Stumpf''') was a German farmer, accused of [[werewolf]]ery, [[witchcraft]] and [[cannibalism]]. He was known as 'the Werewolf of Bedburg'.
== Sources == The most comprehensive source on the case is a pamphlet of 16 pages published in [[London]] in 1590, the translation of a German print of which no copies have survived. The English pamphlet, of which two copies exist (one in the British Museum and one in the Lambeth Library), was rediscovered by occultist [[Montague Summers]] in 1920. It describes Stumpp's life and alleged crimes and the trial, and includes many statements from neighbours and witnesses of the crimes.<ref>Catherine Orenstein, ''Little Red Riding Hood Uncloaked: Sex, Morality, and the Evolution of a Fairy Tale'', p. 91, {{ISBN|0-465-04125-6}}</ref> Summers reprints the entire pamphlet, including a woodcut, on pages 253 to 259 of his work ''The Werewolf''.
Additional information is provided by the diaries of Hermann von Weinsberg, a Cologne alderman, and by a number of illustrated broadsheets, which were printed in southern Germany and were probably based on the German version of the London pamphlet. The original documents seem to have been lost during the wars of the centuries that followed.
Contemporary reference was made to the pamphlet by [[Edward Fairfax]] in his firsthand account of alleged witch persecution of his own daughters in 1621.<ref>Edward Fairfax, Daemonologica: A Discourse on Witchcraft, p.97, R. Ackrill: Harrogate, 1882.</ref>
== Biography == Peter Stumpp's name is also spelled as ''Peter Stube'', ''Peter Stub'',<ref>Edward Fairfax, Daemonologica: A Discourse on Witchcraft, p.97, R. Ackrill: Harrogate, 1882.</ref> ''Peter Stubbe'', ''Peter Stübbe'' or ''Peter Stumpf'', and other aliases include such names as Abal Griswold, Abil Griswold, and Ubel Griswold. The name "Stump" or "Stumpf" may have been given him as a reference to the fact that his left hand had been cut off leaving only a stump, in German "Stumpf". {{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} It was alleged that as the "werewolf" had its left forepaw cut off, then the same injury proved the guilt of the man. Stumpp was born at the village of Epprath near the country-town of [[Bedburg]] in the [[Electorate of Cologne]]. His actual date of birth is not known, as the local church registers were destroyed during the [[Thirty Years' War]] (1618–1648). He was a wealthy farmer of his rural community.<ref>''Encyclopedia of Serial Killers {{ISBN|1-85648-328-2}} p. 165</ref> During the 1580s he seems to have been a widower with two children; a girl called Beele (Sybil), who seems to have been older than fifteen years old, and a son of an unknown age.
== Accusations == During 1589, Stumpp had one of the most lurid and famous [[werewolf]] trials of history. After being stretched on a [[Rack (torture device)|rack]], and before further torture commenced,<ref>{{cite book|last=Friedrich|first=Otto|title=Going crazy: An inquiry into madness in our time|edition=2nd prt.|year=1976|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=0-671-22174-4|page=48}}</ref> he confessed to having practiced [[black magic]] since he was twelve years old. He claimed that the [[Devil]] had given him a magical [[Belt (clothing)|belt or girdle]], which enabled him to [[Metamorphosis|metamorphose]] into "the likeness of a greedy, devouring wolf, strong and mighty, with eyes great and large, which in the night sparkled like fire, a mouth great and wide, with most sharp and cruel teeth, a huge body, and mighty paws." Removing the belt, he said, made him transform back to his human form. No such belt was ever found after his arrest.
For twenty-five years, Stumpp had allegedly been an "insatiable bloodsucker" who gorged on the flesh of [[goat]]s, [[sheep|lamb]]s, and [[sheep]], as well as men, women, and children. Being threatened with torture he confessed to killing and eating fourteen children, two [[Pregnancy|pregnant]] women, whose [[fetus]]es he ripped from their wombs and "ate their hearts panting hot and raw,"<ref>''Encyclopedia of Serial Killers {{ISBN|1-85648-328-2}} p. 165</ref> which he later described as "dainty morsels."<ref>{{cite web|last=Wagner|first=Stephen|title=The Werewolf of Bedburg|url=http://paranormal.about.com/od/werewolves/a/The-Werewolf-Of-Bedburg.htm}}</ref> One of the fourteen children was his own son, whose [[brain]] he was reported to have devoured.
Not only was Stumpp accused of being a serial murderer and [[Cannibalism|cannibal]], but also of having an [[incest]]uous relationship with his daughter,<ref>''Encyclopedia of Serial Killers {{ISBN|1-85648-328-2}} p. 165</ref> who was sentenced to die with him, and that he had coupled with a distant relative, which was also considered to be incestuous according to the law. In addition to this he confessed to having had intercourse with a [[succubus]] sent to him by the Devil.
== Execution == [[File:Lukas Mayer 1589 Hinrichtung Peter Stump.jpg|thumb|right|275px|Composite [[woodcut]] print by Lukas Mayer of the execution of Peter Stumpp in 1589 at [[Bedburg]] near Cologne.]] The execution of Stumpp, on October 31, 1589, and of his daughter and mistress, is one of the most brutal on record: he was put to a [[breaking wheel|wheel]], where "flesh was torn from his body", in ten places, with red-hot pincers, followed by his arms and legs. Then his limbs were broken with the blunt side of an axehead to prevent him from returning from the grave, before he was [[decapitation|beheaded]] and his body burned on a pyre. His daughter and mistress had already been flayed and strangled and were burned along with Stumpp's body. As a warning against similar behavior, local authorities erected a pole with the torture wheel and the figure of a wolf on it, and at the very top they placed Peter Stumpp's severed head.
== Background == There are a number of details of the text of the London pamphlet that are inconsistent with the historical facts.
The years during which Stumpp was supposed to have committed most of his crimes (1582–1589) were marked by internal warfare in the [[Electorate of Cologne]] after the abortive introduction of Protestantism by the former Archbishop [[Gebhard Truchsess von Waldburg]]. He had been assisted by Adolf, Count of [[Bad Neuenahr-Ahrweiler|Neuenahr]], who was also the lord of [[Bedburg]].
Stumpp was most certainly a convert to Protestantism. The war brought the invasion of armies of either side, the assaults by marauding soldiers and eventually an epidemic of the [[Bubonic plague|plague]].
When the Protestants were defeated during 1587, Bedburg Castle became the headquarters of Catholic mercenaries commanded by the new lord of Bedburg—Werner, Count of [[Salm-Reifferscheid-Dyck|Salm-Reifferscheidt-Dyck]], who was a staunch Catholic determined to re-establish the Roman faith.
So it is not inconceivable that the werewolf trial was but a barely concealed political trial, with the help of which the new lord of Bedburg planned to bully the Protestants of the territory back into Catholicism. If it had only been just another execution of a werewolf and a couple of witches, as occurred about this time in various parts of Germany, the attendance of members of the aristocracy—perhaps including the new Archbishop and Elector of Cologne—would be surprising. Furthermore, the trial remained a singular event.<ref>[[Sunday Herald]], 1 May 2016</ref>
However, this does not mean that the charges were without basis in fact. The execution of a mere Protestant convert would have been deeply unlikely to have drawn the aristocratic attention Stumpp's trial did, and while it was unlikely for the elite to attend to any given werewolf or witch trial, the sheer scale of Stumpp's alleged crimes would have made it more visible to the public at large and the nobility.
==In popular culture==
The U.S. metal band [[Macabre (band)|Macabre]] recorded a song about Peter Stumpp, titled "The Werewolf of Bedburg"; it can be found on the ''[[Murder Metal]]'' album.
The German horror punk band [[The Other (band)|The Other]] recorded a song about Peter Stumpp, titled "Werewolf of Bedburg"; it can be found on the ''[[Casket Case]]'' album.
In the [[Pine Deep Trilogy]] of novelist and folklorist [[Jonathan Maberry]], Peter Stumpp is the supernatural villain Ubel Griswold. Since Griswold is actually one of Stumpp's historical aliases, Maberry decided to use the name of Ubel Griswold instead of openly telling people that the villain was the famous werewolf Peter Stumpp until later on in the third book of the series, ''Bad Moon Rising''.
In the [[Jim Butcher]] book ''Fool Moon'' there are several characters that use enchanted wolf pelt belts to transform into a wolf form, similar to the belt Peter Stump claimed to have.
A reference to Peter Stumpp is also in [[William Peter Blatty]]'s book, ''[[The Exorcist (novel)|The Exorcist]]''. When Father Karras and Kinderman talk about Satanism they say "Terrible, was this theory, Father, or fact?" "Well, there's William Stumpf, for example. Or Peter. I can't remember. Anyway, a German in the sixteenth century who thought he was a werewolf".
The direct-to-video ''[[Big Top Scooby-Doo!]]'', uses a portion of Lukas Mayer's woodcut of the execution of Stumpp in 1589, though in the movie no mention of Stumpp is made. The portion used depicts a man cutting off a werewolf's left paw (supposedly Stumpp in werewolf form) and a child being attacked by a werewolf. The woodcut scene shown in the film restores the werewolf's left paw and removes the child in the second werewolf's jaws, making it appear as if the swordsman is fighting one of the werewolves while another flees.
In the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' audio drama ''[[Loups-Garoux]]'', Pieter Stubbe was in fact a werewolf. He managed to escape before he was executed and lived for another five centuries. He was defeated by the [[Fifth Doctor]] in Brazil in 2080. It is implied that he ate both the [[Grand Duchess Anastasia Nikolaevna of Russia|Grand Duchess Anastasia]] and [[John Bingham, 7th Earl of Lucan|Lord Lucan]].
Journalist and fiction writer J.E. Reich partially based her short story "The Werewolves of Anspach," which was nominated for multiple awards, on the life of Peter Stumpp.<ref>http://littlefiction.com/beta/JEReich_TheWerewolvesofAnspach.html</ref>
The story of Peter Stumpp was also told in episode 3 of the podcast ''[[Lore (podcast)|Lore]]'', released on April 6, 2015. In 2017, the podcast episode was adapted into the fifth episode of the [[Lore (TV series)|TV series adaptation]] of ''Lore'', where he was played by [[Adam Goldberg]].
The case inspired Neil MacKay's novel, 'The Wolf Trial' (Glasgow: Freight Books, 2016. {{ISBN|978-1-910449-72-1}})
Peter Stump is referenced in 'The Werewolf of Bamburg' by Oliver Potzsch. It briefly mentions his execution and crimes.

Siggi Thordarson
Ziggy
WikiLeaks handles: Singi201, Q, Penguinx | occupation = [[Cyber Security]]
[[Informant]],
[[Spy]] | years_active = | organization = [[WikiLeaks]] | known_for = [[WikiLeaks]], [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], | title = In charge of volunteers and chat rooms at [[WikiLeaks]] | term = 2010-2011 | criminal_charge = Economic crimes,
Sex Crimes (Purchasing sex from adults, and purchasing sex from minors | criminal_penalty = 6 years | criminal_status = Released | website = }} '''Sigurdur Thordarson''' (Sigurður Ingi Þórðarson) was born in 1992 in [[Reykjavík]]. He is known for his involvement with the [[Whistleblowing (ethics)|whistleblowing]] organization [[WikiLeaks]], as well as his interactions with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI). In 2010 he was arrested for stealing and leaking classified information about the bank structure in [[Iceland]].{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Unglingur handtekinn fyrir að stela upplýsingum um Eið Smára|url = http://www.visir.is/unglingur-handtekinn-fyrir-ad-stela-upplysingum-um-eid-smara/article/2010269393239|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} He obtained the information from a lawyer that aided wealthy people in tax evasion, whose name was Gunnar Gunnarsson.{{Cite web|title = Hjálpar auðmönnum að sleppa við skattinn - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/frettir/2010/2/15/hjalpar-audmonnum-ad-sleppa-vid-skattinn/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}} Gunnar worked for an investment firm called Milestone ehf. Gunnar obtained Sigurdur's services to set up computer systems and delete data.{{Cite web|title = Upplýsingastuldur í rannsókn|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2010/02/01/upplysingastuldur_i_rannsokn/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} After Sigurdur was arrested he was introduced to [[Julian Assange]], the editor and founder of [[WikiLeaks]]. Sigurdur started his time there in early 2010, and participated in preparing many of [[Information published by WikiLeaks|WikiLeaks's biggest leaks]]. After a year in WikiLeaks service Sigurdur was suspected of embezzling funds from the WikiLeaks online store.{{Cite web|title = Official WikiLeaks Merchandise Store|url = http://wikileaks.spreadshirt.com/|website = wikileaks.spreadshirt.com|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Wikileaks kærir piltinn sem var yfirheyrður af FBI fyrir fjárdrátt|url = http://www.visir.is/wikileaks-kaerir-piltinn-sem-var-yfirheyrdur-af-fbi-fyrir-fjardratt/article/2013130209409|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} WikiLeaks filed criminal charges against Sigurdur with the [[Icelandic Police|Metropolitan Police of Iceland]], who investigated the case and later dropped it due to lack of evidence. Sigurdur later plead guilty to the embezzlement along with other economic crimes, in 2013.{{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari ákærður fyrir stórfelld svik|url = http://www.ruv.is/frett/siggi-hakkari-akaerdur-fyrir-storfelld-svik|website = RÚV|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Sigurdur was ordered to pay the victims 15 million [[Icelandic króna|ISK]] (roughly [[United States dollar|$]]115,000) [6] ==Information leaks== Sigurdur began leaking information about the Icelandic banking system to the media in late 2009. He leaked information about a number of individuals in the Icelandic banking system, information that showed that individuals were committing illegal acts in relation to banking. One of the leaks Sigurdur leaked was regarding a case called "Vafningsmalid." {{Cite web|title = Vafningsmálið í stærra samhengi|url = http://www.ruv.is/frett/vafningsmalid-i-staerra-samhengi|website = RÚV|access-date = 2016-01-14}} That case involved powerful political persons such as [[Bjarni Benediktsson (born 1970)|Bjarni Benediktsson]] during his time as an MP. Bjarni reported that the case was only a political smear campaign.{{Cite web|title = "Gæti verið farinn í hvert dómsmálið á fætur öðru á móti þessum gæjum" - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/frettir/2013/2/17/eg-gaeti-verid-farinn-i-hvert-domsmalid-faetur-odru/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}} The information published by local news media obtained from Sigurdur also showed that one of Iceland's biggest football stars, [[Eiður Guðjohnsen]], was in deep debt and almost bankrupt. After the information was published, Eiður sued the local newspaper ''[[DV (newspaper)|DV]]'' for publishing this information. ''DV'' lost the case in a lower court, but won an appeal to the Supreme Court of Iceland, stating that the information was a matter for the public. [{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Eiður Smári tapaði - DV mátti fjalla um fjármálin|url = http://www.visir.is/eidur-smari-tapadi---dv-matti-fjalla-um-fjarmalin/article/2011111129364|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}] {{Cite web|title = Fjármál Eiðs Smára áttu erindi við almenning|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2011/01/07/fjarmal_eids_smara_attu_erindi_vid_almenning/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Amongst other information that Sigurdur admitted to have leaked in an interview with the ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine {{Cite web|title = The WikiLeaks Mole|url = https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/the-wikileaks-mole-20140106|website = Rolling Stone|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Ítarlegt viðtal við Sigga hakkara í Rolling Stone|url = http://www.visir.is/itarlegt-vidtal-vid-sigga-hakkara-i-rolling-stone/article/2014140109546|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} was information about local business men Karl Wernersson. He was the owner of the Milestone ehf that was the investment company Sigurdur stole most of the information from. Other names in the documents leaked by Sigurdur included information about [[Birkir Kristinsson]], who was recently convicted of economic crimes while working for [[Glitnir (bank)|Glitnir bank]].{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Birkir Kristinsson dæmdur í fjögurra ára fangelsi|url = http://www.visir.is/birkir-kristinsson-daemdur-i-fjogurra-ara-fangelsi/article/2015151209472|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Some speculate that information from Sigurdur was used as evidence in that case, Sigurdur also leaked a classified report about one of the bigger aluminum plants in Iceland. The report stated that the plant was paying 1/4 of what other aluminum plants in the world are paying for electricity.{{Cite web|title = Segir meðalverð greitt fyrir orku|url = http://www.ruv.is/frett/segir-medalverd-greitt-fyrir-orku|website = RÚV|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Landsvirkjun opinberar orkuverð|url = http://www.ruv.is/frett/landsvirkjun-opinberar-orkuverd|website = RÚV|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Other information leaked by Sigurdur contained information about other local business men such as Gunnar Gunnarsson,{{Cite web|title = Slapp við 700 milljónir - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/frettir/2010/5/20/slapp-vid-700-milljonir/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}} who also has been reported to assist football star [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] in tax affairs. In 2013 Sigurdur got in an argument with [[Birgitta Jónsdóttir]] on [[Twitter]] over the release of the loanbooks of the Glitnir Bank. Sigurdur argued that she had no involvement, but he later stated that he had given her the files years ago.{{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari segist hafa látið Birgittu fá Glitnisskjölin fyrir löngu - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/frettir/2014/1/2/siggi-hakkari-segist-hafa-latid-birgittu-fa-glitnisskjolin-fyrir-longu/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}} In 2009 Sigurdur arrived at the offices of the Special Prosecutor, who investigated the [[2008–11 Icelandic financial crisis|bank collapse in Iceland in 2008]]. Sigurdur reportedly gave them all the information he had on Milestone and other local business men, however instead of using some of the information obtained from Sigurdur in investigation the investigators decided to sell the information.{{Cite web|title = Viðskiptablaðið - Hætta við rannsókn á lögreglumönnum|url = http://www.vb.is/frettir/haetta-vid-rannsokn-logreglumonnum/80478/|website = www.vb.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = "Miklu miklu alvarlegra brot en sérstakur lætur í veðri vaka" - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/frettir/2012/5/25/miklu-miklu-alvarlegra-brot-en-serstakur-laetur-i-vedri-vaka/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}}{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Kæran setti lífið úr skorðum|url = http://www.visir.is/kaeran-setti-lifid-ur-skordum/article/2014709139915|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Leyndarhjúpur um ofurkrimma - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/menning/2013/6/5/leyndarhjupur-um-ofurkrimma-SG0LE9/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}} The case against the two police officers was later dismissed, and it has been reported that the investigators made roughly 30 Million [[Icelandic króna|ISK]] ([[United States dollar|$]]250.000) from the documents. In January 2010 Sigurdur was arrested on suspicion of stealing classified information, that case never made it to the court system and Sigurdur always denied his involvement until the ''Rolling Stone'' interview. Sigurdur was only seventeen years old when he was arrested for leaking the information. ==WikiLeaks connection== [[Kristinn Hrafnsson]], spokesperson for WikiLeaks, claimed that Sigurdur Thordarson had no involvement{{Cite web|title = Vísar öllum tengslum á bug|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2013/02/04/visar_ollum_tengslum_a_bug/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} with the whistleblowing organization and called Sigurdur a "troubled young teen that was a pathological liar and should be institutionalized", although there are many sources that claim that Hrafnsson wasn’t being truthful. In 2013 the movie [[The Fifth Estate (film)|The Fifth Estate]] was released featuring a character based on Sigurdur, he was played by [[Jamie Blackley]], Sigurdur is also mentioned in Domsheitberg's book, during his time with WikiLeaks he reportedly used the handles PenguinX, Singi201 and "Q".{{Cite book|edition = First Edition Thus|title = Inside WikiLeaks: My Time with Julian Assange at the World's Most Dangerous Website|publisher = Crown|date = 2011-02-15|location = New York, NY|isbn = 9780307951915|first = Daniel|last = Domscheit-Berg}} Sigurdur also reportedly saw to it that WikiLeaks came through partially on its promise to give $50.000 to the [[Chelsea Manning]] defense team. Sigurdur managed to get 20% ($10.000) of the funds to Manning's defense team, and was in contact with David Coombs, attorney for Manning, WikiLeaks never donated the rest they had promised. It is unclear what Sigurdur did at WikiLeaks. Many people who are still in the inner circle of WikiLeaks claim that Sigurdur role was minor and that he participated at a very low level in some projects WikiLeaks had, while other sources close to WikiLeaks circle state that his involvement was much greater. One of these people is Tangerine Bolen, the founder of [[Revolution Truth]] and a close friend to film maker [[Michael Moore]]. Tangerine said in an interview with [[RT (TV network)|RT Russia Today]] {{Citation|title = FBI Infiltrates Wikileaks {{!}} Think Tank|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4mJhrPpebY|date = 2013-07-04|accessdate = 2016-01-14}} that although Sigurdur lied often to her, WikiLeaks is understating his involvement, stating that Sigurdur was her "handle" at WikiLeaks [32]. Many other reports state that Sigurdur was a part of WikiLeaks inner circle. One example of that is that if looked at very closely in this video {{Cite web|title = WikiLeaks spoofs MasterCard advert|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/wikileaks/8614990/WikiLeaks-spoofs-MasterCard-advert.html|website = Telegraph.co.uk|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Sigurdur Thordarson's name could be seen on the [[MasterCard]] Gold card that Assange cuts in the video. On many occasions during interviews with Sigurdur, Kristinn Hrafnsson has almost always says that Sigurdur is a pathological liar and should not be trusted. Kristinn has repeatedly called media outlets such as ''[[Reykjavik Grapevine]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', [[BBC News]] and [[Slate (magazine)|''Slate'']] fools for believing the "hype".{{Cite web|title = Kristinn on Siggi: Don't Believe The Hype - The Reykjavik Grapevine|url = http://grapevine.is/mag/articles/2013/07/20/siggi-disclaimer/|website = The Reykjavik Grapevine|access-date = 2016-01-14}} According to [[David Kushner]], the reporter who took the ''Rolling Stone'' interview with Sigurdur, Sigurdur provided ''Rolling Stone'' with over 1 terabyte of data (1000 gigabytes ) to the paper about WikiLeaks, and said that either Sigurdur was the real deal or this was the biggest and most elaborate lie in the digital age. Also number of photos related to articlesabout the extradition hearings in London July 2011, show Sigurdur escorting Julian to the court house {{Cite news|title = Julian Assange: from hero to zero|url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/nov/02/assange-hero-zero-swedes-pitiable|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2011-11-02|access-date = 2016-01-27|issn = 0261-3077|first = Karin|last = Olsson|last2 = Stockholm}} as well as a video where Sigurdur holds the press from Julian while he enters a cab {{Citation|title = Julian Assange leaves final hearing - as court defers extradition decision - 13/07/2011|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tqBjeeF7QKs|date = 2011-07-13|accessdate = 2016-01-27|last = andriuskk}} ==FBI connection== In August 2011, Sigurdur contacted the [[United States Embassy in Reykjavik]] and claimed he had information about an ongoing criminal investigation in the United States, and requested a meeting. The day after Sigurdur was summoned to the embassy, where he gave diplomatic staff official documents showing that Sigurdur was who he claimed he was. The day after the meeting with the embassy official the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] sent a private jet with eight federal agents and a prosecutor to question Sigurdur. The FBI gave Icelandic authorities notice that they were questioning Sigurdur in relation to an co-investigation that [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] and [[LulzSec]] were about to infiltrate Icelandic government systems. After the authorities found out Sigurdur was being questioned about WikiLeaks, the FBI was asked to leave Iceland. The FBI left the country a few days later but took Sigurdur with them to Denmark where questioning continued.{{Cite web|title = WikiLeaks reports the FBI to Danish police|url = http://www.thelocal.dk/20140713/wikileaks|website = www.thelocal.dk|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Sigurdur was subsequently allowed to return to Iceland. In 2012 Sigurdur met with the federal agents on a number of occasions, and was flown to [[Copenhagen]] where Sigurdur was provided a room in a luxury hotel.{{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari á lúxushótelum|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2013/08/15/siggi_hakkari_a_luxushotelum/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Sigurdur was allowed to return to Iceland after every meeting. Sigurdur met with the FBI again in [[Washington D.C.]] and spent a couple of days with them there. The final meeting that Sigurdur said took place with the FBI was during a course Sigurdur was enrolled in at [[Aarhus]] in Denmark, teaching IT Security. Sigurdur met with the agents there and handed over several hard drives. it is reported that Sigurdur got $5,000 for his assistance and that he was on the FBI's payroll.{{Cite web|title = WikiLeaks Volunteer Was a Paid Informant for the FBI|url = https://www.wired.com/2013/06/wikileaks-mole/|website = WIRED|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = 'Siggi hakkari' á launaskrá FBI|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2013/06/27/siggi_hakkari_a_launaskra_fbi/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} In 2013 Sigurdur was also summoned to the General Committee of the [[Althing|Icelandic Parliament]] after days of being discussed in the Parliament. There Sigurdur was questioned about his involvement in the FBI case.{{Cite web|title = mbl.is - mbl.is|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/knippi/3044/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} The then-[[Minister of the Interior (Iceland)|Minister of the Interior]] [[Ögmundur Jónasson]] said in Parliament that Sigurdur was young and the FBI meant him to be a "spy" within the WikiLeaks organization.{{Cite web|title = Íslendingurinn hugsaður sem tálbeita|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/innlent/2013/02/14/hugsadur_sem_talbeita/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} At the parliament hearing Sigurdur arrived with two bodyguards.{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Kom með lífverði á nefndasvið Alþingis|url = http://www.visir.is/kom-med-lifverdi-a-nefndasvid-althingis/article/2013130229823|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} =="Spy Computer"== In January 2011 it was revealed in Icelandic media that a computer had been found within closed sections of the Parliament.{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Njósnatölva fannst á þingi - hafa Wikileaks grunaða|url = http://www.visir.is/njosnatolva-fannst-a-thingi---hafa-wikileaks-grunada/article/2011956569254|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} According to reports it was alleged that WikiLeaks was suspected of placing the computer inside the Parliament. Bjarni Benediktsson the MP Sigurdur leaked information about comments found on the computer {{Cite web|title = Bein árás á Alþingi|url = http://www.mbl.is/frettir/sjonvarp/54648/|website = mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Sigurdur was questioned about his involvement in this case, but has always denied any involvement in it. ''[[Morgunblaðið]]'', Iceland's largest newspaper published on the front page on January 31, 2011 that a local reporter for the paper ''DV'' was suspected of obtaining the information from Sigurdur. The reporter was said to be under investigation for receiving the information from Sigurdur and manipulating Sigurdur into leaking the information and placing the computer inside Parliament.{{Cite web|title = Blaðamaður DV með réttarstöðu grunaðs manns|url = http://www.mbl.is/greinasafn/grein/1366005/|website = www.mbl.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.visir.is/krefur-agnesi-um-haerri-miskabaetur/article/2011842122304|title = Krefur Agnesi um hærri miskabætur|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} The reporter sued the newspaper for libel and won the case. ''Morgunblaðið'' withdrew the report and issued an apology to the reporter on December 7. There was a report in the Icelandic media that stated that specialists were now checking whether parliament phones were spied on by [[WikiLeaks]].{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Hlerun í Alþingi: "Grafalvarlegt ef satt reynist"|url = http://www.visir.is/hlerun-i-althingi---grafalvarlegt-ef-satt-reynist-/article/2013712079921|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Kanna hvort símar Alþingis voru hleraðir|url = http://www.visir.is/kanna-hvort-simar-althingis-voru-hleradir/article/2013131209224|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} ''[[Wired (website)|Wired]]'' published chat logs that indicated such.{{Cite web|title = It’s Not a WikiLeak: Assange-Manning Chat Logs Surface on Army Website|url = https://www.wired.com/2013/12/wikileaks-assange-manning/|website = WIRED|access-date = 2016-01-14}} This is believed to support the claim that Sigurdur is involved with the spy computer somehow.{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Wikileaks með hljóðupptökur úr Alþingishúsinu|url = http://www.visir.is/wikileaks-med-hljodupptokur-ur-althingishusinu/article/2013131209295|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} [[Birgitta Jónsdóttir]] issued a statement stating that she had never heard of any recordings.{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Birgitta aldrei séð né heyrt um hljóðupptökurnar|url = http://www.visir.is/birgitta-aldrei-sed-ne-heyrt-um-hljodupptokurnar/article/2013131209209|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} The case is still under investigation with no official suspects.{{Cite web|title = Grunaður hakkari við Pressuna: Það hefur enginn talað við mig um njósnatölvuna á Alþingi!|url = http://www.pressan.is/frettir/lesafrett/grunadur-hakkari-vid-pressuna-thad-hefur-enginn-talad-vid-mig-um-njosnatolvuna-a-althingi|website = Pressan.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Njósnatölva á skrifstofum Alþingis tortímdi sjálfri sér - Grunsemdir féllu á WikiLeaks|url = http://www.pressan.is/frettir/lesafrett/njosnatolva-a-skrifstofum-althingis-tortimdi-sjalfri-ser---grunsemdir-fellu-a-wikileaks|website = Pressan.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Ritstjóri DV: Rakalaust bull að við tengjumst njósnatölvu - Enginn blaðamaður yfirheyrður|url = http://www.pressan.is/frettir/lesafrett/ritstjori-dv-rakalaust-bull-ad-vid-tengjumst-njosnatolvu---enginn-bladamadur-yfirheyrdur|website = Pressan.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = "Njósnatölva": Lögregla hefur engan grunaðan|url = http://eyjan.pressan.is/frettir/2011/01/22/njosnatolva-logregla-hefur-engan-grunadan/|website = eyjan.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} ==Anonymous and LulzSec== During his time at WikiLeaks it has also been reported that Sigurdur ordered attacks on Icelandic governmental infrastructures such as the servers hosting the Ministry's websites www.stjornarradid.is and www.landsnet.is. Those [[DDoS]] attacks were successful for a few hours. This was all done after an Icelandic business man that owns an Icelandic data center asked Sigurdur to do so. It has also been reported that Sigurdur ordered [[Hector Monsegur]] (Sabu) and his team to attack [[Icelandic Police|Icelandic State Police]] servers. This all happened during Sabu's time as an FBI informant. It is reported that Sigurdur obtained the unpublished version of a report about the surveillance unit at the U.S Embassy in Reykjavik.{{Cite web|url = https://www.innanrikisraduneyti.is/media/2010/Skyrsla-um-konnun-embaettis-rikislogreglustjora.pdf|title = Skýrsla um könnun embættis ríkislögreglustjóra|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}{{Cite web|title = Ríkissaksóknara send málefni er varða starfsemi eftirlitssveitar við bandaríska sendiráðið á Íslandi {{!}} Fréttir {{!}} Innanríkisráðuneytið|url = https://www.innanrikisraduneyti.is/dmr/frettir/nr/24357|website = Innanríkisráðuneytið|access-date = 2016-01-14}} It has also been reported that Sigurdur Thordarson was WikiLeaks's connection to the hacker world. Many reports have indicated that persons part of Anonymous and LulzSec reported to Sigurdur. That was covered partially in the book ''We are Anonymous''.{{Cite web|title = We Are Anonymous by Parmy Olson - Books - Random House Books Australia|url = http://www.randomhouse.com.au/books/parmy-olson/we-are-anonymous-9780434022083.aspx|website = Random House Australia|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Reports state that Sigurdur obtained many leaks through this method that WikiLeaks later published, such as [[Kissinger cables|The Kissinger cables]] and [[Syria Files|The Syria Files]].It is unknown how WikiLeaks or Sigurdur obtained the information, though chat logs between Sigurdur and Hector Monsegur a.k.a. Sabu have surfaced.{{Cite web|title = Here's What It Looks Like When Two Hacker FBI Informants Try To Inform On Each Other|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/06/28/heres-what-it-looks-like-when-two-hacker-fbi-informants-try-to-inform-on-each-other/#2715e4857a0b7e486573cc00|website = Forbes|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = SABU Hands over the "Syria Files" to Wikileaks staffer Sigurdur Thordarson in WikiLeaks related News|url = http://www.wikileaks-forum.com/-wikileaks-related-news/23/sabu-hands-over-the-syria-files-to-wikileaks-staffer-sigurdur-thordarson/31055/|website = www.wikileaks-forum.com|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Some people also speculate whether the attack on the website of the Central Intelligence Agency was ordered by Sigurdur as a test to see whether "Sabu" had really as good skills and people as he claimed, it is believed that communications between "Sabu" and Sigurdur escalated after the CIA attack,https://www.rt.com/news/cia-site-claims-attack-807/ ==Public appearance== In November 2013 Sigurdur went to Norway to speak about his journey for the organization YATA. This is the first and only known time that Sigurdur has spoken about his story in public, except in media interviews.{{Cite web|title = Hvordan en 17-åring ender opp hos Wikileaks og FBI - YATA Norge|url = http://yata.no/hvordan-en-17-aring-ender-opp-hos-wikileaks-og-fbi/|website = YATA Norge|access-date = 2016-01-14}} ==Prison convictions== In 2012 Sigurdur was questioned about sexual misconduct, accused of purchasing sex from a seventeen year old teenager. At the time Sigurdur was 18 years old. Sigurdur denied the charges but was found guilty in late 2013 and received 8 months in prison.{{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari dæmdur fyrir að misnota dreng - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/frettir/2013/11/19/siggi-braut-sautjan-ara-pilt-WRMWNX/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}} In 2012 WikiLeaks filed criminal charges against Sigurdur for embezzlement. Sigurdur denied the charges and the case was later dismissed. He was later arrested in the summer of 2013 on charges of financial fraud. At that time the WikiLeaks case was brought back up, and Sigurdur was indicted on charges of embezzlement and financial fraud. In 2014 Sigurdur was ordered to pay WikiLeaks 7 million ISK (roughly $55,000) as well as being sentenced to prison for 2 years for embezzlement and financial fraud. Sigurdur plead guilty to all counts.{{Cite web|url = http://www.visir.is/grunadur-ad-minnsta-kosti-um-tiu-milljon-krona-fjarsvik/article/2013130609696|title = Grunaður að minnsta kosti um tíu milljón króna svik|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} In those cases Sigurdur was ordered to pay the victims 15 million ISK (roughly $115.000), Sigurdur received a two-year prison sentence in those cases.{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Siggi "The Hacker" receives a two year prison sentence|url = http://www.visir.is/siggi--the-hacker--receives-a-two-year-prison-sentence/article/2014141229831|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-19}} In 2012 Sigurdur was arrested for trying to blackmail a large Icelandic candy factory, it then turned out that Sigurdur had no involvement in that scheme at all and the case was later dismissed.{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Mál á hendur Sigga hakkara fellt niður - tveir aðrir grunaðir um að kúga fé út úr Nóa Síríus|url = http://www.visir.is/mal-a-hendur-sigga-hakkara-fellt-nidur---tveir-adrir-grunadir-um-ad-kuga-fe-ut-ur-noa-sirius/article/2013130829738|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} In January 2014 Sigurdur was arrested on charges of sex crimes. He was believed to be a flight risk and possibly sabotaging the investigation and therefore placed in solitary confinement for six weeks. An indictment was later issued and Sigurdur was charged with purchasing sex from a minor and purchasing sex. Initially 11 charges were filed but only nine made it to an indictment. Five of the charges were purchasing sex from a minor and four were purchasing sex from an adult. The victims ranged from the age of 15-20, all male, during which Sigurdur was 18-21. Sigurdur plead guilty to all counts and received 3 years for that,{{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari grunaður um alvarleg kynferðisbrot gegn nokkrum piltum|url = http://www.pressan.is/Frettir/Lesa_Innlent/siggi-hakkari-grunadur-um-alvarleg-kynferdisbrot-gegn-nokkrum-piltum?pressandate=20140214|website = Pressan.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari grunaður um 11 kynferðisbrot|url = http://www.ruv.is/frett/siggi-hakkari-grunadur-um-11-kynferdisbrot|website = RÚV|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Sigurður grunaður um fleiri kynferðisbrot|url = http://www.ruv.is/frett/sigurdur-grunadur-um-fleiri-kynferdisbrot|website = RÚV|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Sigurdur negotiated the damages to his victims and paid 8.6 million ISK (roughly $66,000) {{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari þarf að greiða hátt í tíu milljónir í miskabætur - DV|url = http://www.dv.is/frettir/2015/9/25/siggi-hakkari-tharf-ad-greida-hatt-i-tiu-milljonir-i-miskabaetur/|website = DV|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}}{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Siggi hakkari í þriggja ára fangelsi fyrir kynferðisbrot gegn níu drengjum|url = http://www.visir.is/siggi-hakkari-i-thriggja-ara-fangelsi-fyrir-kynferdisbrot-gegn-niu-drengjum/article/2015150929238|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}}{{Cite web|title = Vísir - Dómurinn yfir Sigga hakkara: Bauð unglingspiltum allt að 100 milljónir, bíla og einbýlishús|url = http://www.visir.is/domurinn-yfir-sigga-hakkara--baud-unglingspiltum-allt-ad-100-milljonir,-bila-og-einbylishus/article/2015150929149|website = visir.is|access-date = 2016-01-14}} Sigurdur started to serve his sentence of 6 years in 2014. He is incarcerated in [[Litla-Hraun]], Iceland's only maximum security prison, which is located 30 minutes outside of Reykjavik.{{Cite web|title = Fangelsið Litla-Hrauni {{!}} Fangelsi.is|url = http://www.fangelsi.is/fangelsi-rikisins/fangelsid-litla-hrauni/|website = www.fangelsi.is|access-date = 2016-01-19|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160127112748/http://www.fangelsi.is/fangelsi-rikisins/fangelsid-litla-hrauni|archivedate = 2016-01-27|df = }} Sigurdur has been ordered to pay roughly 31 millions ISK (roughly $236,000) in total damages. According to reports the sum has been paid.{{Cite web|title = Siggi hakkari þarf að greiða fullt af fólki skaðabætur - Nútíminn|url = http://nutiminn.is/siggi-hakkari-tharf-ad-greida-fullt-af-folki-skadabaetur/|website = Nútíminn|access-date = 2016-01-14|language = is-IS}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} [[Category:1992 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Reykjavík]] [[Category:WikiLeaks]] [[Category:Icelandic prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Iceland]] [[Category:People convicted of fraud]] [[Category:People convicted of sex crimes]]
