{{Other uses of|Border Patrol}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox law enforcement agency | agencyname = United States Border Patrol | abbreviation = USBP | patch = Patch of the United States Border Patrol.png | patchcaption = Right sleeve patch | logo = Logo of the United States Border Patrol.svg | logocaption = Seal and left sleeve patch of the United States Border Patrol | badge = Badge of the United States Border Patrol.svg | badgecaption = USBP badge | flag = Flag of the United States Border Patrol.svg | flagcaption = USBP flag | motto = Honor First | formed = {{start date and age|1924|5|28}} | country = United States | federal = yes | sizearea = 20,000 lineal miles | legaljuris = INA 235 & INA 287. Title 8 USC, 18 USC, 19 USC & 21 USC | speciality = border | headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | sworntype = Border Patrol Agents | sworn = Congress Mandated 21,370 | governingbody = [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] | chief1name = [[Carla Provost]]<ref name="USnews">{{cite web|title=Border Patrol Names Carla Provost Acting Chief |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/arizona/articles/2017-04-26/border-patrol-names-carla-provost-acting-chief |date=April 26, 2017 |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |accessdate=June 28, 2017}}</ref> | chief1position = Chief, U.S. Border Patrol | parentagency = [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]] | officetype = Agent | website = [http://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders United States Border Patrol] }}
The '''United States Border Patrol''' ('''USBP''') is an American [[federal police|federal law enforcement agency]] whose mission is to detect and prevent [[illegal immigration|illegal aliens]], terrorists and terrorist weapons from entering the United States, and prevent illegal trafficking of people and contraband.<ref>{{cite web|title=Border Patrol Overview: Mission|publisher=U.S. Customs and Border Protection|date=January 5, 2011 |url=http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_ohs/overview.xml |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017094418/http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_ohs/overview.xml |archivedate=October 17, 2009}}</ref> It is the mobile, uniformed law enforcement arm of [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]] (CBP), a component of the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS).<ref>{{cite web|title=Along U.S. Borders |publisher=Department of Homeland Security|date=September 18, 2015|url=https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507155800/https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders |archivedate=May 7, 2016}}</ref>
With 19,887 agents,<ref name=FY2017staffing/> the Border Patrol is one of the largest law enforcement agencies in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/about/accomplish/previous_year/fy11_stats/typical_day_fy11.ctt/typical_day_fy11.pdf|title=On a Typical Day in Fiscal Year 2011|publisher=U.S. Customs and Border Protection|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216131424/http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/about/accomplish/previous_year/fy11_stats/typical_day_fy11.ctt/typical_day_fy11.pdf|archive-date=February 16, 2013|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref> For fiscal year 2017, Congress enacted a budget of $3,805,253,000 for the Border Patrol.<ref name=FY2017sectors>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/assets/documents/2017-Dec/BP%20Budget%20History%201990-2017.pdf|title=United States Enacted Border Patrol Program Budget by Fiscal Year|website=U.S. Customs and Border Protection|publisher=U.S. Department of Homeland Security|access-date=June 24, 2018 }}</ref>
The current chief of the Border Patrol is [[Carla Provost]].<ref name="USnews"/>
==History== {{refimprove section|date=February 2017}} Mounted [[Watchman (law enforcement)|watchmen]] of the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service|United States Department of Commerce and Labor]] patrolled the border in an effort to prevent illegal crossings as early as 1904, but their efforts were irregular and undertaken only when resources permitted. The inspectors, usually called "mounted guards", operated out of [[El Paso, Texas]]. Though they never totaled more than 75, they patrolled as far west as [[California]] trying to restrict the flow of illegal Chinese immigration.
In March 1917, Congress authorized a separate group of mounted guards, often referred to as "mounted inspectors". Most rode on horseback, but a few operated automobiles, motorcycles and boats. Although these inspectors had broader arrest authority, they still largely pursued Chinese immigrants trying to avoid the [[National Origins Act]] and [[Chinese Exclusion Act]] of 1882. These patrolmen were Immigration Inspectors, assigned to inspection stations, and could not watch the border at all times. [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] soldiers along the southwest border performed intermittent border patrolling, but this was secondary to "the more serious work of military training." Immigrants encountered illegally in the U.S. by the Army were directed to the immigration inspection stations. [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Rangers]] were also sporadically assigned to patrol duties by the state, and their efforts were noted as "singularly effective". {{triple image|left/right/center|Badge of the United States Border Patrol (1924-1940).png|115|Badge of the United States Border Patrol (1992-2003).svg|130|Badge of the United States Border Patrol.svg|130|Former badge when the agency was under the Dept. of Labor (1920–1940)|The former badge, when the agency was under the Dept. of Justice (1940–2003)|The current badge after the agency became a part Homeland Security (2003–)|Badge of the United States Border Patrol, circa 1939.|Badge of the United States Border Patrol, circa 1999.|Badge of the United States Border Patrol, circa 2013.}} [[File:BorderPatrol.png|right|thumb|During the 1940 Border Patrol expansion, four newly hired agents from the northeastern states drove this new pursuit vehicle from the Ford factory in Detroit to El Paso where they would receive training.]] [[File:2ndThompsonTraining.png|right|thumb|A Border Patrol Agent practice firing a Thompson submachine gun near El Paso in 1940.]] The U.S. Border Patrol was founded on May 28, 1924 (by the [[Labor Appropriation Act of 1924]]<ref name="CBP-4-2014">{{cite web |title=Border Patrol History|url=https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/history|publisher=DepartmentU.S. Customs and Border Protection|accessdate=January 29, 2017|date=April 3, 2014|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170126205831/https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/history|archivedate=January 26, 2017}}</ref>) as an agency of the [[United States Department of Labor]] to prevent [[illegal entry|illegal entries]] along the [[Mexico–United States border]] and the [[Canada–United States border|Canada–U.S. border]]. The first Border Patrol station began operations in Detroit, Michigan in June 1924.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/border-patrol-sectors/detroit-sector-selfridge-angb-michigan/detroit-station|title=Detroit Station {{!}} U.S. Customs and Border Protection |website=www.cbp.gov|access-date=September 21, 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161215232051/https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/border-patrol-sectors/detroit-sector-selfridge-angb-michigan/detroit-station|archivedate=December 15, 2016}}</ref> A second station in El Paso, Texas began operations in July 1924.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/border-patrol-sectors/el-paso-sector-texas|title=El Paso Sector Texas {{!}} U.S. Customs and Border Protection|website=www.cbp.gov|access-date=September 21, 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161215234918/https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/border-patrol-sectors/el-paso-sector-texas|archivedate=December 15, 2016|df=}}</ref> Additional operations were established along the Gulf Coast in 1927 to perform crewman control to ensure that foreign crewmen departed on the same ship on which they arrived.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_sectors/detroit_sector_mi/detroit_welcome.xml|work=CBP|title=Detroit Welcome|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304075347/http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_sectors/detroit_sector_mi/detroit_welcome.xml|archivedate=March 4, 2013}}</ref> In 1932, the Border Patrol was divided into two offices. Mexican border operations were directed from [[El Paso, Texas]] and Canadian border operations were directed from [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. The Canadian border operations from Detroit employed more men than the El Paso operations along the Mexican border because of a focus on the prevention of liquor smuggling during prohibition. [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]]'s Executive Order 6166 formed the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]] (INS) in 1933 by consolidation of the Bureau of Immigration and the Bureau of Naturalization. Following the outbreak of [[World War II]] in Europe, Border Patrol staffing doubled to 1,500 in 1940, and the INS was moved from the Department of Labor to the [[U.S. Department of Justice]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.borderpatrolmuseum.com/history/border-patrol-history.html|title=A History of the United States Border Patrol |publisher=National Border Patrol Museum|accessdate=April 10, 2013|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130908070136/http://borderpatrolmuseum.com/history/border-patrol-history.html |archivedate=September 8, 2013}}</ref> Additional stations were temporarily added along the Gulf Coast, Florida and the [[East Coast of the United States|Eastern Seaboard]] during the 1960s after Fidel Castro triumphed in the [[Cuban Revolution]] and that was followed by the [[Cuban Missile Crisis]]. INS was decommissioned in March 2003 when its operations were divided between CBP, [[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services]], and [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]].
In the wake of the attacks of September 11, the Border Patrol was placed under the umbrella of the Department of Homeland Security, and preventing terrorists and terrorist weapons from entering the United States was added to its mission. The Border Patrol's traditional mission continued: deterring, detecting and apprehending illegal immigrants and individuals involved in the illegal drug trade who generally entered the United States at places other than through designated [[ports of entry]]. The Border Patrol also erected{{when|date=June 2014}} 33 permanent [[United States Border Patrol Interior Checkpoints|interior checkpoints]] near the southern border of the United States.
For fiscal year 2017, the nationwide total of Border Patrol agents was 19,437.<ref name=FY2017staffing>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/assets/documents/2017-Dec/BP%20Staffing%20FY1992-FY2017.pdf|title=United States Border Patrol Agent Nationwide Staffing by Fiscal Year|website=U.S. Customs and Border Protection|publisher=U.S. Department of Homeland Security|access-date=June 24, 2018 }}</ref> Southwest border sectors were patrolled by 16,605 agents, while 2,048 other agents staffed northern border sectors and 212 were assigned to coastal border sectors.<ref name=FY2017staffing/> Agents primarily patrol the [[Mexico–United States border]], where they control drug trafficking and illegal immigration.<ref name="who">{{cite web|title=Who we are and what we do |date=September 3, 2008|publisher=U.S. Customs and Border Protection |url=http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/who_we_are.xml|accessdate=June 1, 2009 |work=CPB.gov|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510084324/http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/who_we_are.xml|archivedate=May 10, 2009}}</ref>
The majority of Border Patrol agents are [[Minority group|minorities]]. According to 2016 data, [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latinos]] comprise slightly more than 50% of the Border Patrol.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mejia|first=Brittny|date=April 23, 2018 |title=Many Latinos answer call of the Border Patrol in the age of Trump|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-citizens-academy-20180323-htmlstory.html|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=June 24, 2018 }}</ref>
==Strategy==
===1986: Employer sanctions and interior enforcement=== [[File:United States Border Patrol Mexico.jpg|thumb|right|Border Patrol Agents with a [[Hummer]] and [[Eurocopter AS350 Écureuil|Astar]] patrol for illegal entry into the United States]] The Border Patrol's priorities have changed over the years. In 1986, the [[Immigration Reform and Control Act]] placed renewed emphasis on controlling illegal immigration by going after the employers that hire illegal aliens. The belief was that jobs were the magnet that attracted most illegal aliens to come to the United States. The Border Patrol increased interior enforcement and Form I-9 audits of businesses through an inspection program known as "employer sanctions". Several agents were assigned to interior stations, such as within the [[Livermore Sector (U.S. Border Patrol)|Livermore Sector]] in Northern California.
Employer sanctions never became the effective tool it was expected to be by Congress. Illegal immigration continued to swell after the 1986 amnesty despite employer sanctions. By 1993, Californians passed [[Proposition 187]], denying benefits to illegal aliens and criminalizing illegal aliens in possession of forged green cards, identification cards, and Social Security numbers. It also authorized police officers to question non-nationals as to their immigration status and required police and sheriff departments to cooperate and report illegal aliens to the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service|INS]]. Proposition 187 drew nationwide attention to illegal immigration.
====Checkpoint stations==== [[United States Border Patrol Interior Checkpoints]] are inspection stations operated by the USBP within {{convert|100|mi}} of an international border (with Mexico or Canada) or any U.S. coastline, or in the [[Florida Keys]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Tina|last=Starr|title=Local man's film highlights plight of migrant farm workers|url=https://www.vermontfolklifecenter.org/exhibits-feed/the-golden-cage |location=Barton, Vermont|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=August 9, 2018}}</ref>
====El Paso Sector's Operation Hold the Line==== [[El Paso, Texas|El Paso]] Sector Chief Patrol Agent [[Silvestre Reyes]] started a program called "Operation Hold the Line". In this program, Border Patrol agents would no longer react to [[illegal entry|illegal entries]] resulting in apprehensions, but would instead be forward deployed to the border, immediately detecting any attempted entries or deterring crossing at a more remote location. The idea was that it would be easier to capture illegal entrants in the wide open deserts than through the urban alleyways. Chief Reyes deployed his agents along the [[Rio Grande]], within eyesight of other agents. The program significantly reduced illegal entries in the urban part of El Paso, however, the operation merely shifted the illegal entries to other areas.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
====San Diego Sector's Operation Gatekeeper==== [[File:Border patrol at the beach, San Diego county.jpg|thumb|right|Patrolling the beach in San Diego County, California]] San Diego Sector tried [[Silvestre Reyes]]' approach of forward deploying agents to deter illegal entries into the country. Congress authorized the hiring of thousands of new agents, and many were sent to San Diego Sector.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} In addition, Congressman [[Duncan Hunter]] became a major proponent of border fencing; surplus [[Marston Mat|military landing mats]] were obtained to use as an initial border fence.<ref>{{Cite news|title=With Congress's Blessing, a Border Fence May Finally Push Through to the Sea|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/04/us/with-congresss-blessing-a-border-fence-may-finally-push-through-to-the-sea.html |newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 4, 2005|access-date=December 8, 2015|issn=0362-4331|first=John M.|last=Broder|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151028081350/http://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/04/us/with-congresss-blessing-a-border-fence-may-finally-push-through-to-the-sea.html|archivedate=October 28, 2015}}</ref> Stadium lighting, ground sensors and infra-red cameras were also placed in the area. Eventually the primitive landing mat fence was replaced with a modern triple fence line<ref>{{Cite news |title=What's a Double-Layer Fence |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2006/09/whats_a_doublelayer_fence.html|newspaper=Slate|date=September 25, 2006 |access-date=December 8, 2015|issn=1091-2339|first=Daniel|last=Engber|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210230722/http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2006/09/whats_a_doublelayer_fence.html|archivedate=December 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Border Control: Revised Strategy Is Showing Some Positive Results|url=http://www.gao.gov/products/GGD-95-30|website=www.gao.gov|accessdate=December 8, 2015|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211132003/http://www.gao.gov/products/GGD-95-30|archivedate=December 11, 2015}}</ref> that begins over one hundred yards into the Pacific Ocean at Imperial Beach, CA and ends more than 13 miles (19 km) inland on Otay Mesa where the mountains begin.
====Northern border==== [[File:USBP snow M14 2017.jpg|thumb|right|An agent armed with an [[M14 rifle]] tracking someone in harsh winter conditions on the northern border.]]
[[File:Border Patrol at Canadian border in Beebe Plain, Vermont.jpg|thumb|right|Border crossing to Canada at [[Beebe Plain, Vermont]]]] Through agency [[Whistleblower Protection Act|whistleblowers]], Agent Mark Hall and Agent Robert Lindemann, it was revealed that in 2001, the Border Patrol had approximately 324 agents assigned along the [[Canada–United States border]].<ref>[http://www.cnsnews.com/node/20451 Border Patrol Agrees To Reinstate Whistleblowers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130722115727/http://www.cnsnews.com/node/20451 |date=July 22, 2013}}. CNS News. Retrieved on July 23, 2013.</ref> Northern border staffing had been increased by 1,128 agents to 1,470 agents by the end of fiscal year 2008, and is projected to expand to 1,845 by the end of fiscal year 2009, a sixfold increase. Resources that support Border Patrol agents include the use of new technology and a more focused application of air and marine assets.
The northern border sectors are (west to east): Blaine (Washington), Spokane (Washington), Havre (Montana), Grand Forks (North Dakota), Detroit (Selfridge ANGB, Michigan), Buffalo (New York), Swanton (Vermont), and Houlton (Maine).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/border-patrol-sectors|title=Border Patrol Sectors {{!}} U.S. Customs and Border Protection|website=www.cbp.gov|access-date=September 21, 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830194302/https://www.cbp.gov/border-security/along-us-borders/border-patrol-sectors |archivedate=August 30, 2016}}</ref>
===The new strategy=== [[File:US Mexico border surveillance.jpg|right|thumb|Cameras add "Smart Border" surveillance.]]
In November 2005, the U.S. Border Patrol published an updated national strategy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/national_bp_strategy.ctt/national_bp_strategy.pdf|title=National Border Patrol Strategy|accessdate=November 28, 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051112235923/http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/national_bp_strategy.ctt/national_bp_strategy.pdf|archivedate=November 12, 2005}}</ref> The goal of this updated strategy is operational control of the United States border. The strategy has five main objectives: #Apprehend terrorists and terrorist weapons illegally entering the United States; #Deter illegal entries through improved enforcement; #Detect, apprehend, and deter smugglers of humans, drugs, and other contraband; #Use "smart border" technology; and #Reduce crime in border communities, improving quality of life.
==Capabilities== [[File:MQ-9 Reaper CBP.jpg|thumb|right|[[General Atomics MQ-9 Reaper|MQ-9 Predator B]] UAS operated by United States Customs and Border Protection]] [[File:Border Patrol ATV IMG 5278.jpg|thumb|right|Border Patrol all-terrain vehicles]] The United States border is a barely discernible line in uninhabited deserts, canyons, or mountains. The Border Patrol utilizes a variety of equipment and methods, such as electronic sensors placed at strategic locations along the border, to detect people or vehicles entering the country illegally. Video monitors and night vision scopes are also used to detect illegal entries. Agents patrol the border in vehicles, boats, aircraft, and afoot. In some areas, the Border Patrol employs horses, all-terrain motorcycles, bicycles, and snowmobiles. Air surveillance capabilities are provided by [[unmanned aerial vehicle]]s.<ref name="overview">{{cite web |title=Border Patrol overview|date=August 22, 2008|publisher=U.S. Customs and Border Protection |url=http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_ohs/overview.xml|accessdate=June 1, 2009|work=CPB.gov |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017094418/http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_ohs/overview.xml|archivedate=October 17, 2009}}</ref>
The primary activity of a Border Patrol Agent is "Line Watch". Line Watch involves the detection, prevention, and apprehension of terrorists, illegal aliens and smugglers of aliens at or near the land border by maintaining surveillance from a covert position; following up on leads; responding to electronic sensor, television systems and aircraft sightings; and interpreting and following tracks, marks, and other physical evidence. Major activities include traffic check, traffic observation, city patrol, transportation check, administrative, intelligence, and anti-smuggling activities.<ref name="who" />
Traffic checks are conducted on major highways leading away from the border to detect and apprehend illegal aliens attempting to travel further into the interior of the United States after evading detection at the border, and to detect illegal narcotics.<ref name="overview" />
Transportation checks are inspections of interior-bound conveyances, which include buses, commercial aircraft, passenger and freight trains, and marine craft.<ref name="overview" />
Marine Patrols are conducted along the coastal waterways of the United States, primarily along the Pacific coast, the Caribbean, the tip of Florida, and Puerto Rico and interior waterways common to the United States and Canada. Border Patrol conducts border control activities from 130 marine craft of various sizes. The Border Patrol maintains watercraft ranging from blue-water craft to inflatable-hull craft, in 16 sectors, in addition to headquarters special operations components.<ref name="overview" />
Horse and bike patrols are used to augment regular vehicle and foot patrols. Horse units patrol remote areas along the international boundary that are inaccessible to standard all-terrain vehicles. Bike patrol aids city patrol and is used over rough terrain to support linewatch.<ref name="overview" /> Snowmobiles are used to patrol remote areas along the northern border in the winter.
==Expansion== [[File:Detroit - Inside Greyhound Bus Station - P1080197.JPG|thumb|right|U.S. Border Patrol Agents at the [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound]] bus station in [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]] in February 2011. Immigration checks on trains, buses, and highways within 100 miles of the northern border have become more common.<ref name=COE2011>{{cite web|date=January 9, 2011|title=Far From Border, U.S. Detains Foreign Students|first=Colin|last=Woodard|periodical=The Chronicle of Higher Education |url=http://chronicle.com/article/Far-From-Canada-Aggressive/125880/|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130721084340/http://chronicle.com/article/Far-From-Canada-Aggressive/125880|archivedate=July 21, 2013}}</ref>]] In 1992, the United States Border Patrol had approximately 4,139 Patrol Agents on the job. Attrition in the Border Patrol was normally at 5%. From 1995–2001 annual attrition rose to above 10%, which was a period when the Border Patrol was undergoing massive hiring. In 2002 the attrition rate climbed to 18%. The 18% attrition was largely attributed to agents transferring to the [[Federal Air Marshals]] after [[9/11]]. Since that time the attrition rate has decreased. Congress increased journeyman Border Patrol Agent pay from a [[General Schedule (US civil service pay scale)|GS-9 rate to a GS-11 rate]] in 2002. The Border Patrol Marine Position was created in 2009 (BPA-M). This position will be updated to a GS-12 position sometime in 2010 or 2011. Border Patrol Field Training Officers may possibly be updated in 2010 to a temporary GS-12 pay rate. In 2005, Border Patrol attrition dropped to 4% and remains in the area of 4% to 6% as of 2009.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Nuñez-Neto|first=Blas|title=Border security: The role of the U.S. Border Patrol|publisher=Congressional Research Service|date=January 25, 2006|format=PDF |url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/govdocs/crs//data/2006/upl-meta-crs-8464/RL32562_2006Jan25.pdf|page=35|accessdate=June 1, 2009 |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030025902/http://digital.library.unt.edu/govdocs/crs//data/2006/upl-meta-crs-8464/RL32562_2006Jan25.pdf|archivedate=October 30, 2008}}</ref>
The [[Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act]] of 2004 (signed by President Bush on December 17, 2004) authorized hiring an additional 10,000 agents, "subject to appropriation". This authorization nearly doubled the Border Patrol manpower from 11,000 to 20,000 agents by 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|first=Erin|last=Kelly|title=Governor:Ariz. besieged |url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2010/06/03/20100603brewer-obama-discuss-border.html|publisher=Florida Today |location=Melbourne, Florida|pages=5A|date=June 3, 2010|accessdate=August 9, 2018}}</ref> As of 2016, roughly half of the agents are [[Latino Americans]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Carroll |first=Rory |title=Life as a Mexican American on the Border Patrol: 'The system is not broken' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/dec/12/mexican-american-border-patrol-agent-vincente-paco |newspaper=Guardian |location=United Kingdom |date=December 12, 2016 |access-date=December 31, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230213122/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/dec/12/mexican-american-border-patrol-agent-vincente-paco |archivedate=December 30, 2016}}</ref>
The [[Secure Fence Act of 2006|Secure Fence Act]], signed by President George W. Bush on October 26, 2006, has met with much opposition. In October 2007, environmental groups and concerned citizens filed a restraining order hoping to halt the construction of the fence, set to be built between the United States and Mexico. The act mandates that the fence be built by December 2008. Ultimately, the United States seeks to put fencing around the {{convert|1945|mi|km|adj=on}} border, but the act requires only {{convert|700|mi|km}} of fencing. DHS secretary Michael Chertoff has bypassed environmental and other oppositions with a waiver that was granted to him by Congress in Section 102 of the act, which allows DHS to avoid any conflicts that would prevent a speedy assembly of the fence.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Coyle|first=Marcia|title=Waivers for border fence challenged: Environmental groups take their complaints to Supreme Court|newspaper=The Recorder|date=March 3, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/02/us/02fence.html|title=Government issues waiver for fencing along border|author=Archibold, Randal C.|newspaper=New York Times|date=April 2, 2008|accessdate=April 2, 2008|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927063615/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/02/us/02fence.html|archivedate=September 27, 2011}}</ref>
This action has led many environment groups and landowners to speak out against the impending construction of the fence.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Conservation groups call for an immediate halt to construction of border fence in San Pedro National Conservation Area |newspaper=US Newswire|date=October 5, 2007}}</ref> Environment and wildlife groups fear that the plans to clear brush, construct fences, install bright lights, motion sensors, and cameras will scare wildlife and endanger the indigenous species of the area.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Gordon, David George|title=A 'grande' dispute|magazine=National Geographic World|date=May 2000|page=4}}</ref> Environmentalists claim that the ecosystem could be affected because a border fence would restrict movement of all animal species, which in turn would keep them from water and food sources on one side or another. Desert plants would also feel the impact, as they would be uprooted in many areas where the fence is set to occupy.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Cohn, Jeffrey P.|title=The environmental impacts of a border fence|journal=BioScience|year=2007|volume=57|issue=1|page=96|doi=10.1641/B570116 |url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/full/10.1641/B570116|accessdate=June 1, 2009}}</ref>
Property owners in these areas fear a loss of land. Landowners would have to give some of their land over to the government for the fence. Citizens also fear that communities will be split. Many students travel over the border every day to attend classes at the University of Texas at Brownsville. Brownsville mayor Pat Ahumada favors alternative options to a border fence. He suggests that the Rio Grande be widened and deepened to provide for a natural barrier to hinder illegal aliens and drug smugglers.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Expansive border fence stirs fights over land|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=87854099|series=[[Tell Me More]]|network=NPR|airdate=2008-03-03|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516121141/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=87854099|archivedate=May 16, 2008}}</ref>
==Special Operations Group== [[File:USBP-SRT-New Orleans.jpg|thumb|right|Border Patrol agents—including the Border Patrol Tactical Unit (BORTAC) and Laredo Sector Special Response Team—conduct a room-by-room search of a New Orleans hotel following [[Hurricane Katrina]] ]] * [[Border Patrol Tactical Unit]] (BORTAC) * [[Border Patrol, Search, Trauma and Rescue]] (BORSTAR) * [[Mobile Response Team]] (MRT)
==Other specialized programs== [[File:CBT Canine Enforcement Program.jpg|thumb|150px|left|BORSTAR canine team conducting rappeling training]] In 2007, the U.S. Border Patrol created the Special Operations Group (SOG) headquartered in El Paso, TX to coordinate the special operations units of the agency.<ref>[http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/ 2007 State of the U.S. Border Patrol video] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051120220227/http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/ |date=November 20, 2005}}</ref> The U.S. Border Patrol has a number of other specialized programs and details. Marine Patrol – In the [[riverine]] environments of the northern and southwestern borders of the continental United States, the Border Patrol conducts border control activities from the decks of marine craft of various sizes. Since 2006, the U.S. Border Patrol has relinquished its [[littoral]] law enforcement missions in the [[Great Lakes]] and [[territorial seas]] to the [[Office of Air and Marine]]. The U.S. Border Patrol maintains over 130 vessels, ranging from blue-water craft to inflatable-hull craft, in 16 sectors, in addition to Headquarters special operations components.[[File:US Border Patrol Special Operations HQ.jpg|thumb|right|Sign for U.S. Border Patrol Special Operations Group on [[Biggs Army Airfield]], [[Fort Bliss]], El Paso, Texas]] <ref>[http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_ohs/overview.xml Border Patrol Overview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017094418/http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_ohs/overview.xml |date=October 17, 2009}}. CBP.gov. Retrieved on July 23, 2013.</ref> [[Police dog|K9]] Units, [[Mounted police|Mounted Patrol]], Bike patrol, Sign-cutting (tracking), [[Snowmobile]] unit, Infrared scope unit, [[Criminal intelligence|Intelligence]], [[People smuggling|Anti-smuggling]] Investigations Unit (ASU/DISRUPT, Border Criminal Alien Program, Multi-agency Anti-Gang Task Forces (regional & local units), [[Guard of honour|Honor Guard]], [[Pipes and Drums]], [[Chaplain]], [[Peer Support]], Mobile Surveillance Unit.
==Lifesaving== [[File:CBP Rescue Beacon.jpg|thumb|right|upright|This rescue beacon states in English and Spanish: "Attention: You Cannot Walk To Safety From This Point! You Are In Danger of Dying If You Do Not Summon Help! If You Need Help, Push Red Button, U.S. Border Patrol Will Arrive in One Hour, Do Not Leave This Locaton"]] "Operation Gatekeeper" was launched in 1994 to stop migrants from crossing illegally into the United States. The strategy included increased enforcement and extensive fencing near border cities, with the twofold purpose of deflecting migrants to remote areas where they could more easily be detected and apprehended, as well as using the formidable mountains, deserts, and [[Rio Grande]] as a deterrent to easy passage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://citation.allacademic.com//meta/p_mla_apa_research_citation/2/3/7/1/5/pages237154/p237154-11.php|title=Prevention-Through-Deterrence and Death Mitigation: Fantasy and Fetishes in Border Law's Symbolic Order|last=Fan|first=Mary D.|publisher=All Academic |accessdate=September 21, 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060010/http://citation.allacademic.com//meta/p_mla_apa_research_citation/2/3/7/1/5/pages237154/p237154-11.php|archivedate=March 4, 2016}}</ref> The newly erected [[Mexico–United States barrier]]—which at some remote locations is no more than a fence—has also forced migrants and human traffickers to seek out remote desert locations in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas where they may attempt crossing.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. Border Patrol Southwest Border Fence Maps |publisher=U.S. Customs and Border Protection|date=February 13, 2013 |url=http://nemo.cbp.gov/borderpatrol/2435_southwest.pdf |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923085638/http://nemo.cbp.gov/borderpatrol/2435_southwest.pdf |archivedate=September 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kolb|first=Joseph J.|title=Fort Hancock, Texas: Where a fence and hope for illegals ends |publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=July 1, 2013|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/07/01/fort-hancock-texas-where-fence-and-hope-for-illegals-ends/|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922222449/http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/07/01/fort-hancock-texas-where-fence-and-hope-for-illegals-ends/|archivedate=September 22, 2013}}</ref> The "funnel effect" created by both these strategies has contributed to the [[Migrant deaths along the Mexico–United States border|deaths]] of thousands of migrants, whose remains are often found in the hot desert or freezing mountains.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Continued Humanitarian Crisis at the Border: Undocumented Border Crosser Deaths Recorded by the Pima County Office of the Medical Examiner, 1990–2012|publisher=University of Arizona|year=2013 |url=http://bmi.arizona.edu/sites/default/files/border_deaths_final_web.pdf|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130920111514/http://bmi.arizona.edu/sites/default/files/border_deaths_final_web.pdf |archivedate=September 20, 2013}}</ref>
As early as 1998, the former [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]] implemented the Border Safety Initiative in response to concerns about the number of migrants injured or killed while attempting to cross the border. It was noted that Border Patrol agents routinely supplied water, food, and medical care to migrants.<ref name="GAO">{{cite web |title=Border-Crossing Deaths Have Doubled Since 1995; Border Patrol’s Efforts to Prevent Deaths Have Not Been Fully Evaluated|publisher=U.S. Government Accountability Office |date=August 2006|url=http://www.gao.gov/assets/260/251173.pdf|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140930091636/http://www.gao.gov/assets/260/251173.pdf |archivedate=September 30, 2014}}</ref> That same year, [[Border Patrol, Search, Trauma and Rescue]] (BORSTAR), a specialized unit trained in emergency search and rescue, was established with the purpose of assisting injured or stranded migrants at remote locations.<ref name="BP-A">{{cite web|title=Border Patrol Search, Trauma, and Rescue (BORSTAR) |publisher=U.S. Customs and Border Protection |date=May 2009 |url=http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/newsroom/fact_sheets/border/border_patrol/borstar.ctt/borstar.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926195059/http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/newsroom/fact_sheets/border/border_patrol/borstar.ctt/borstar.pdf |archivedate=September 26, 2013}}</ref>
In 2002, the first "rescue beacons" were installed in desert areas considered especially dangerous.<ref name="Polliard">{{cite web |last=Polliard|first=Brittany|title=Rescue Beacons ("Panic Poles")|publisher=National Border, National Park: A History of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument|url=http://organpipehistory.com/orpi-a-z/rescue-beacons-panic-poles/|accessdate=June 24, 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901194443/http://organpipehistory.com/orpi-a-z/rescue-beacons-panic-poles/ |archivedate=September 1, 2013}}</ref> The beacons are solar powered and highly visible, and have a button which alerts Border Patrol agents by radio signal, after which a helicopter or ground unit is dispatched.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stine |first=Mark|title=Border Patrol Rescue Beacons|publisher=KOLD News Tucson|url=http://www.tucsonnewsnow.com/global/story.asp?s=6235228|accessdate=June 24, 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923012846/http://www.tucsonnewsnow.com/global/story.asp?s=6235228|archivedate=September 23, 2013}}</ref> U.S. Senator [[Bill Frist]] commented in 2006: "these beacons, I believe, are an absolutely vital link in our border security system... We know that beacons work: CBP has already saved dozens of people based entirely on beacon alerts."<ref name="Polliard"/> The Border Patrol frequently publishes reports about stranded and injured individuals rescued at beacon locations.
During a 12-month period in 2011–12, Border Patrol agents made 1,312 rescues along the Mexico-United States border, nearly half occurring in the Tucson Sector.<ref>{{cite web|title=United States Border Patrol Sector Profile – Fiscal Year 2012|publisher=U.S. Customs and Border Protection|date=February 4, 2013 |url=http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/usbp_statistics/usbp_fy12_stats/usbp_sector_profile.ctt/usbp_sector_profile.pdf|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20130303081836/http://www.cbp.gov/linkhandler/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/usbp_statistics/usbp_fy12_stats/usbp_sector_profile.ctt/usbp_sector_profile.pdf |archivedate=March 3, 2013}}</ref>
==Border Patrol Sectors== [[File:CBP Sectors Map.jpg|thumb|right|A map of Border Patrol sectors]] [[File:U.S. Border Patrol Holding Rooms, Fort Brown Station, Brownsville, Texas (2014).jpg|thumb|right|Holding room at Fort Brown Station, [[Brownsville, Texas]]]] [[File:Border Patrol in Montana.jpg|thumb|right|Border Patrol in Montana.]] There are 20 Border Patrol sectors, each headed by a Sector Chief Patrol Agent.
==Training== All Border Patrol agents spend a minimum of 13 weeks at the Border Patrol Academy (if they are fluent in Spanish) in [[Artesia, New Mexico]], which is a component of the [[Federal Law Enforcement Training Center]] (FLETC). Those who are not fluent in Spanish spend an additional eight weeks at the Academy for a total of 21 weeks. Border Patrol Agent Trainees are instructed in courses including; criminal law, nationality law, and administrative immigration law, police sciences, self-defense and arrest techniques, firearms training with pistol, shotgun and rifle, police vehicle driving, and other Border Patrol / federal law enforcement subjects.
Once they arrive back at their duty station, Trainees then must graduate from the Field Training Officer (FTO) program, an on-the-job training program, which varies in length from a minimum of 12 weeks to a maximum of over 16 weeks long, depending on the practical demands of the duty station and local management. They must also successfully complete the Post Academy Training Program, an extension of the Border Patrol Academy where Trainees complete additional classroom-based training over the course of their first nine months back at their duty station.
The marksmanship skills of Border Patrol agents ranks among the best in the United States. At the National Police Shooting Championships in 2012, Border Patrol agents placed first, second or third in each of the 29 shooting matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://npsc.nra.org/past-results.aspx|title=Past National Police Shooting Championships Results |publisher=National Rifle Association of America|access-date=|accessdate=September 21, 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161126064759/http://npsc.nra.org/past-results.aspx|archivedate=November 26, 2016}}</ref>
==Appearance== [[File:CBP female officers going aboard a ship.jpg|thumb|right|Officers boarding a ship that's entered US waters]] ===Uniforms=== The Border Patrol, c. 2007, wore the following types of uniforms: [[File:CBP Officers pay tribute 2007.jpg|thumb|right|A color guard composed of CBP officers and USBP agents at a Washington, D.C. ceremony in May 2007.]] *Summer Dress uniform – The summer dress uniform consists of a short-sleeve, olive-green dress shirt (which may or may not have blue shoulder straps), brass [[nameplate]], badge, olive-green [[slacks]] with a blue stripe running the length of the seam, and black dress shoes or dress boots. A green, straw [[campaign hat]] is worn with this uniform. * Winter Dress uniform – The winter dress uniform consists of a long-sleeve, olive green dress shirt, navy-blue [[clip-on tie]] with a brass [[tie tack]], olive-green [[ike jacket]] with blue accents (shoulder straps and cuffs), brass nameplate, badge, olive-green slacks with a blue stripe running the length of the seam, and black dress shoes or dress boots. a green, felt campaign hat with a black, leather [[hat band]] is worn with this uniform. *Ceremonial Dress uniform – Worn primarily by border patrol [[Guard of honour|honor guard]] agents, the ceremonial dress uniform is roughly identical to the winter dress uniform, with the exception that a [[tunic]] is worn with this uniform, rather than an ike jacket. White, cloth gloves are also worn with this uniform. * Rough duty uniform – The rough duty uniform consists of a green, long-sleeve or short-sleeve work shirt, green [[cargo pants]], and black work boots. a green [[baseball cap]] is typically worn with this uniform. **There are also specialized rough duty uniforms for marine patrol (riverine), northern border cold weather, horse patrol and bike patrol agents. * Highland Uniform – Worn by members of the United States Border Patrol Pipes and Drums in the performance of their official duties, this uniform includes a kilt made of the official Border Patrol Tartan, custom made ceremonial coat, glengarry, sporran and spats. * Organization patches – The Border Patrol wears two: ** The CBP patch is worn on the right sleeves of the uniform. It contains the DHS seal against a black background with a "keystone" shape. A "keystone" is the central, wedge-shaped stone in an arch, which holds all the other stones in place. ** Border Patrol agents retain the circular legacy Border Patrol patch, which is worn on the left sleeve.
The Border Patrol uniform is getting its first makeover since the 1950s to appear more like military fatigues and less like a police officer's duty garb.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2007/08/17/news/sandiego/18_64_318_16_07.txt|title=Border Patrol uniform gets first makeover since the 1950s|author=Spagat, Elliot|date=August 16, 2007|newspaper=North County Times|accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626063521/http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2007/08/17/news/sandiego/18_64_318_16_07.txt|archivedate=June 26, 2009}}</ref> Leather belts with brass buckles are being replaced by nylon belts with quick-release plastic buckles, slacks are being replaced by lightweight cargo pants, and shiny badges and nameplates are being replaced by cloth patches.

===Newton-Azrak Award for Heroism=== The Border Patrol's highest honor is the Newton-Azrak Award for Heroism. This Award is bestowed to Border Patrol Agents for extraordinary actions, service; accomplishments reflecting unusual courage or bravery in the line of duty; or an extraordinarily heroic or humane act committed during times of extreme stress or in an emergency.
This award is named for Border Patrol Inspectors Theodore Newton<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odmp.org/officer.php?oid=9933|title=Border Patrol Inspector Theodore L. Newton Jr.|publisher=The Officer Down Memorial Page|accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927192945/http://www.odmp.org/officer.php?oid=9933|archivedate=September 27, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and George Azrak,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odmp.org/officer.php?oid=1368|title=Border Patrol Inspector George F. Azrak|publisher=The Officer Down Memorial Page|accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930014719/http://www.odmp.org/officer.php?oid=1368|archivedate=September 30, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> who were murdered by two drug smugglers in San Diego County in 1967.

==Equipment==
===Weapons=== [[File:CBP M14.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A Border Patrol Honor Guard Agent carrying an [[M14 rifle]].]] Border Patrol agents are issued the [[H&K P2000]] double action LEM (Law Enforcement Modification) pistol in [[.40 S&W]] caliber. It can contain as many as 13 rounds of ammunition (12 in the magazine and one in the chamber). Up until 1994 the Border Patrol issued its Patrol Agents a .357 Magnum revolver as their duty sidearm, a [[Smith & Wesson]] or [[Ruger]] model large frame, six shot revolver. The Border Patrol preferred this weapon because it did not jam in harsh conditions, like those of the southwestern border, and also because of the strong "stopping" power of the .357 Magnum cartridge. Although up until 1994 Patrol Agents could purchase a weapon from the agency list of approved authorized personal weapons for duty carry. This list included the Glock Models 17 and 19 pistols in 9mm, the [[SIG Sauer P220]] pistol in .45 ACP caliber, the [[Colt Python]] .357 Magnum revolver, and the [[Smith & Wesson Model 19|Smith & Wesson Model 19/66]] .357 Magnum revolver. The Border Patrol adopted the [[Beretta 92|Beretta Model 96D]], a .40 S&W caliber semi-automatic pistol (modified for Double-Action Only) (with 11-round capacity magazines) as its duty issue sidearm in 1995. The .40 S&W caliber jacketed hollow-point cartridge was adopted because of its excellent "stopping" power and its superior ballistic characteristics over the 9mm cartridge. In late 2006 the H&K P2000 pistol was adopted as the Border Patrol's primary duty sidearm. The H&K Model USP Compact pistol, H&K Model P2000SK (sub-compact) and Beretta M96D .40 S&W caliber pistols are authorized as secondary sidearms. [[File:Border Patrol Agent in Nogales, Arizona.jpg|thumb|right|Patrolling a tunnel in [[Nogales, Arizona]].]]
Like many other law enforcement agencies, the 12 [[gauge (bore diameter)|gauge]] [[Remington Model 870]] is the standard pump-action shotgun. The Border Patrol issue Model 870 has been modified by Scattergun Technologies to Border Patrol specifications including: a 14-inch barrel, a five-shot capacity magazine, a composite stock with pistol grip, and night sights with a tactical "ghost-ring" rear sight. The old Border Patrol "anti-bandit" units used to use a 12-gauge, semi-automatic shotgun with a sawed-off barrel. This weapon had the designated name of a "Sidewinder." The USBP anti-bandit units were decommissioned in the late 1980s.
Border Patrol agents also commonly carry the [[.223 Remington|.223]] caliber Colt [[M4 Carbine|M4 Carbine (M4A1)]] and the [[H&K UMP]] .40 caliber [[submachine gun]]. The [[.308 Winchester|.308]] caliber [[M14 rifle]] is used for ceremonial purposes and by agents who are qualified with the rifle and [[BORTAC]].
As less than lethal options, the Border Patrol uses the FN 303 Launcher. The FN 303 fires plastic pellet balls containing OC (Oleoresin Capsicum) Pepper dust. The plastic pellet balls burst on impact spraying the suspect with OC Pepper dust and also act as an impact projectile. The Border Patrol also issues its agents OC Pepper spray canisters, tasers and a collapsible/telescopic (or telescoping) steel police baton.
===Transportation=== [[File:Presdunebuggy.jpg|thumb|right|Former U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] rides in a U.S. Border Patrol [[dune buggy]] in 2006]] [[File:U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Riverine Unit Patrols Rio Grande River Border in Air-Boat.jpg|thumb|right|Patrolling the [[Rio Grande]] in an [[airboat]] at [[Laredo, Texas]], 2013.]] [[File:Office of CBP Air and Marine helicopter and boats.jpg|right|thumb|Helicopter and boats]] [[File:South Texas, Border Patrol Agents, McAllen Horse Patrol Unit.jpg|thumb|right|A USBP Horse Patrol in southern Texas.]] Unlike in many other law enforcement agencies in the United States, the Border Patrol operates over 10,000 [[SUV]]s and pickup trucks, which are known for their capabilities to move around in any sort of terrain. These vehicles may have individual revolving lights (strobes or LEDs) and/or light bars and sirens and/or have their bumpers removed or have off-road suspension and tires. An extensive modernization drive has ensured that these vehicles are equipped with wireless sets in communication with a central control room. Border Patrol vehicles may also have equipment such as emergency first aid kits. Some sectors make use of sedans like the [[Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptor]] or the [[Dodge Charger (LX)#Police package version|Dodge Charger]] as patrol cars or high speed "interceptors" on highways. The border patrol has approx 2,000 sedans. The Border Patrol also operates all-terrain vehicles, motorcycles, snowmobiles, and small boats in riverine environments.
In 2005, all Border Patrol and ICE aircraft operations were combined under CBP's [[Office of Air and Marine]]. All CBP vessel operations within the Customs Waters and on the high seas are conducted by Marine Interdiction Agents of the Office of Air and Marine.
Color schemes of Border Patrol vehicles are either a long green stripe running the length of the vehicle (older vehicles) or a broad green diagonal stripe (newer vehicles) on the door. Most Border Patrol vehicles are painted predominantly white. During the 1960s to mid-1980s Border Patrol vehicles were painted a light green.
The Border Patrol also extensively uses horses for remote area patrols. {{As of|2005}}, the [[U.S. Border Patrol]] has 205 horses. Most are employed along the [[Mexico–United States border]]. In [[Arizona]], these animals are fed special processed feed pellets so that their wastes do not spread non-native plants in the national parks and wildlife areas they patrol.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.enn.com/top_stories/article/1731|title=Border Patrol horses get special feed that helps protect desert ecosystem |author=Rostien, Arthur H.|newspaper=Environmental News Network|date=June 9, 2005|accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903075838/http://www.enn.com/top_stories/article/1731|archivedate=September 3, 2009}}</ref>
==Killed in the line of duty== Since 1904, the Border Patrol has lost 123 officers in the line of duty, more than any other federal law enforcement agency during that time period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odmp.org/agency/4830-united-states-department-of-homeland-security-customs-and-border-protection-united-states-border-patrol-us-government|title=United States Department of Homeland Security – Customs and Border Protection – Border Patrol|publisher=Officer Down Memorial Page|accessdate=June 24, 2018|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110504052750/http://www.odmp.org/agency/4830-united-states-department-of-homeland-security---customs-and-border-protection---border-patrol-u.s.-government|archivedate=May 4, 2011}} Note: The [[United States Marshals Service]] has suffered more ''total'' line of duty deaths, though over a longer time period (see {{cite web |url=http://www.odmp.org/agency/3955-united-states-department-of-justice-united-states-marshals-service-us-government |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 20, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921053726/http://www.odmp.org/agency/3955-united-states-department-of-justice-united-states-marshals-service-us-government |archivedate=September 21, 2013}}).}</ref>

==Armed incursions== On August 7, 2008, [[Mexican Army|Mexican troops]] crossed the border into Arizona and held a U.S. Border Patrol Agent at gunpoint. Agents stationed at [[Ajo, Arizona]] said that the Mexican soldiers crossed the border into an isolated area southwest of Tucson and pointed rifles at the agent, who has not been identified. The Mexicans withdrew after other U.S. agents arrived on the scene.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}}
On March 14, 2000, 16 Mexican soldiers in two humvees chased a Border Patrol agent near Santa Teresa, New Mexico, while another agent came under gunfire. Backup arrived and the soldiers were detained. The Mexican government said the soldiers got lost. The U.S. State Department ordered them sent back to Mexico along with their weapons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsmax.com/insidecover/mexican_troops_border/2008/08/06/119516.html|title=Mexican troops cross border, hold border agent |author=Meyers, Jim|publisher=Newsmax.com|date=August 6, 2008|accessdate=June 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822095841/http://www.newsmax.com/insidecover/mexican_troops_border/2008/08/06/119516.html|archivedate=August 22, 2008}}</ref>
==Death threats== Testifying in front of the [[United States Senate]], Border Patrol Chief Mark Morgan said that the Border Patrol is the one of the most assaulted law enforcement agencies;<ref>{{cite news |last=Gehrke |first=Joel |date=September 13, 2016 |title=Border Patrol chief: Agents 'most assaulted' law officers in the U.S. |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/border-patrol-chief-agents-most-assaulted-law-officers-in-the-u.s./article/2601675 |newspaper=Washington Examiner |access-date=December 31, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510100658/http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/border-patrol-chief-agents-most-assaulted-law-officers-in-the-u.s./article/2601675 |archivedate=May 10, 2017}}</ref> since 2006, over seven thousand agents of the Border Patrol were attacked.<ref>{{cite news |title=Rock Throwing Attacks on Border Patrol Agents on the Rise |url=http://www.krgv.com/story/33849922/rock-throwing-attacks-on-border-patrol-agents-on-the-rise |newspaper=KRGV |location=Rio Grande Valley, Texas |date=December 1, 2016 |access-date=December 31, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170101091729/http://www.krgv.com/story/33849922/rock-throwing-attacks-on-border-patrol-agents-on-the-rise |archivedate=January 1, 2017}}</ref> On numerous occasions USBP agents have been fired upon from the Mexican side of the international border. Intelligence gathering has discovered bounties being placed on Patrol Agents to be paid by criminal smuggling organizations upon the confirmed murder or kidnapping of a U.S. Border Patrol Agent. In 2008, intelligence learned of a two-million-dollar contract for the murder of a Border Patrol Agent. In 2009 Border Patrol Agent Rosas was murdered in an ambush while on patrol; a bounty may have been paid to the assassins.<ref>[http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_officer_memorial/alpha_listing_agents/q_z/robert_rosas.xml Robert W. Rosas, Jr.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100307145530/http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/border_security/border_patrol/border_patrol_officer_memorial/alpha_listing_agents/q_z/robert_rosas.xml |date=March 7, 2010 }}. CBP.gov. Retrieved on July 23, 2013.</ref>
==Criticisms== ''See also:'' [[Criticism of the United States government#Criticism of agencies|Criticism of the United States government § Criticism of agencies]]
===Ramos and Compean=== In February 2005, Border Patrol Agents [[Ignacio Ramos]] and [[Jose Compean]] were involved in an incident while pursuing a van in [[Fabens, Texas]]. The driver, later identified as Aldrete Davila, was shot by Agent Ramos during a scuffle. Davila escaped back into Mexico, and the agents discovered that the van contained a million dollars worth of marijuana (about 750 pounds). None of the agents at the scene orally reported the shooting, including two supervisors: Robert Arnold, first-line Supervisor and Jonathan Richards, a higher ranking Field Operations Supervisor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Odd_News/2006/08/28/Uproar-over-US-Border-Patrol-shooting/UPI-58451156792824/|title=Uproar over U.S. Border Patrol shooting|publisher=UPI|date=August 28, 2006|accessdate=March 8, 2012 |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210004405/http://www.upi.com/Odd_News/2006/08/28/Uproar-over-US-Border-Patrol-shooting/UPI-58451156792824/|archivedate=February 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/219384/Ramos-and-Campean-Court-Appeal|title=Ramos and Campean – court appeal|accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120724041451/http://www.scribd.com/doc/219384/Ramos-and-Campean-Court-Appeal|archivedate=July 24, 2012}}</ref> Ramos and Compean were charged with multiple crimes. Ramos was convicted of causing serious bodily injury, assault with a deadly weapon, discharge of a firearm in relation to a crime of violence, and a civil rights violation.<ref name="Seper">{{cite news |last=Seper |first=Jerry|title=Lawmakers seek review of border agent case|publisher=[[The Washington Times]]|date=August 23, 2006 |url=http://washingtontimes.com/national/20060823-122228-3575r.htm|accessdate=December 14, 2006}}</ref> Compeán was found [[Guilty (law)|guilty]] on 11 counts, including discharging a [[firearm]] during the commission of a [[violent crime]], which by itself carries a federally mandated 10-year [[minimum sentence]]. Without that charge, both agents involved would have received far shorter sentences. Ramos was sentenced to 11 years and a day in prison and Compean to 12 years.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gilot |first=Louis |title=Sentence handed to border agents; free until Jan. 17 |publisher=[[El Paso Times]] |date=October 20, 2006 |url=http://www.dailybulletin.com/news/ci_4519632 |accessdate=December 14, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061102190758/http://dailybulletin.com/news/ci_4519632 |archivedate=November 2, 2006}}</ref> Jonathan Richards was promoted to the Patrol Agent in Charge of the Santa Teresa, New Mexico Border Patrol Station soon after the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/da-teen-allegedly-smuggled-aliens-adult/story?id=16150851|title=DA: Teen Who Allegedly Smuggled Aliens Should Be Tried as Adult|date=April 17, 2012|website=ABC News|access-date=September 21, 2016|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412134757/http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/da-teen-allegedly-smuggled-aliens-adult/story?id=16150851|archivedate=April 12, 2016}}</ref> On January 19, 2009, President Bush commuted the sentences of both Ramos and Compean, effectively ending their prison term on March 20, 2009,<ref>Riechmann, Deb. [http://www.startribune.com/politics/national/president/37826749.html?elr=KArksLckD8EQDUoaEyqyP4O:DW3ckUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUUZ "Bush commutes prison sentences of 2 former U.S. border agents"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123050756/http://www.startribune.com/politics/national/president/37826749.html?elr=KArksLckD8EQDUoaEyqyP4O%3ADW3ckUiD3aPc%3A_Yyc%3AaUUZ |date=January 23, 2009 }}, Associated Press, January 19, 2009.</ref> and they were released on February 17, 2009.<ref>[http://www.kfoxtv.com/news/18730957/detail.html Breaking News: Former El Paso Border Patrol Agents Released From Prison] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221005415/http://www.kfoxtv.com/news/18730957/detail.html |date=February 21, 2009}}</ref> The case generated widely differing opinion among various commentators and advocacy groups: civil libertarians asserted the agents used illegal and excessive force, while advocates of tighter border control defended the agents actions.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-Border Patrol Agents Released Early from Prison|publisher=CNN|date=February 17, 2009 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/02/17/border.pardons/|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016223127/http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/02/17/border.pardons/ |archivedate=October 16, 2013}}</ref>
===Death of Sergio Hernandez=== Sergio Adrian Hernandez was a teenager who was shot once and killed on June 7, 2010 by Border Patrol agents under a bridge crossing between [[El Paso, Texas]] and [[Ciudad Juárez|Juarez]], [[Mexico]].<ref name=tsun>{{Cite news |url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/world/2010/06/09/14316756.html|title=U.S. border agent kills Mexican teen|publisher=[[Toronto Sun]]|date=June 9, 2010|accessdate=July 1, 2010}}</ref>
Border Patrol agents claimed that there was a mob that was throwing stones at them.<ref name=tsun/> They also claimed that Hernandez was trying to cross the U.S. border and that he had already tried to do so in the past{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}. For his involvement in the incident, Border Patrol agent Jesus Mesa, Jr. invoked qualified official immunity in his defense.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Doyle |first1=Charles |title=Is There Liability for Cross-Border Shooting? |date=May 22, 2018 |publisher=Congressional Research Service |location=Washington, DC |url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/LSB10135.pdf |accessdate=June 5, 2018}}</ref>
On June 10 the Mexican president [[Felipe Calderón]] called on the United States to launch a "thorough, impartial" probe into the deaths of two Mexican nationals, including the 14-year-old Hernandez, at the hands of U.S. border police: ''"I demand the United States government conduct a thorough, impartial ... investigation, concluding with an establishment of the facts and punishment of the culprits."''<ref name=smh>{{Cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/mexico-urges-us-probe-of-border-deaths-20100611-y0yc.html|title=Mexico urges U.S. probe of border deaths|publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=June 11, 2010|accessdate=July 1, 2010 |deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101207051013/http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/mexico-urges-us-probe-of-border-deaths-20100611-y0yc.html|archivedate=December 7, 2010}}</ref>
On June 12, 2010 the television network [[Univision]] aired cellphone video footage of the incident, after which Mexican legislators called for the extradition of the officer accused of the shooting.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Mexico-Border-Shooting-TV-Station-Airs-Mobile-Footage-Of-US-Border-Agent-Apparently-Shooting-Teen/Article/201006215647790?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15647790_Mexico_Border_Shooting%3A_TV_Station_Airs_Mobile_Footage_Of_US_Border_Agent_Apparently_Shooting_Teen|title=Video Fuels Anger Over Mexico Border Shooting|publisher=[[Sky News]]|date=June 12, 2010|accessdate=July 1, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615091256/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Mexico-Border-Shooting-TV-Station-Airs-Mobile-Footage-Of-US-Border-Agent-Apparently-Shooting-Teen/Article/201006215647790?lid=ARTICLE_15647790_Mexico_Border_Shooting%3A_TV_Station_Airs_Mobile_Footage_Of_US_Border_Agent_Apparently_Shooting_Teen&lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_0|archivedate=June 15, 2010|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/2010/0610/US-Border-Patrol-shooting-new-video-threatens-Mexico-drug-war-cooperation/%28page%29/2|title=U.S. Border Patrol shooting (new video) threatens Mexico drug war cooperation|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|accessdate=July 1, 2010|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614184058/http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/2010/0610/US-Border-Patrol-shooting-new-video-threatens-Mexico-drug-war-cooperation/%28page%29/2|archivedate=June 14, 2010}}</ref>

===Death of Jose Antonio Elena Rodriguez=== {{Main|Killing of Jose Rodriguez}}
As the [http://www.wola.org/ Washington Office on Latin America]'s [http://borderfactcheck.tumblr.com/post/33715644831/is-firing-bullets-at-rock-throwers-a-justified-use-of Border Fact Check site] points out, a similar incident occurred in October 2012 when 16-year-old Jose Antonio Elena Rodriguez was killed in downtown Nogales, Mexico when a Border Patrol Agent, Lonnie Swartz, opened fire at a group of people allegedly throwing rocks at him; Rodriguez was shot seven times in the back. WOLA and other human rights organizations assert that "...[L]aw enforcement experience offers a series of non-lethal responses to rock throwing incidents along the U.S.-Mexico border," such as pepper ball launchers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Meyer|first=Maureen|title=Is firing bullets at rock throwers a justified use of force by the Border Patrol?|url=http://borderfactcheck.tumblr.com/post/33715644831/is-firing-bullets-at-rock-throwers-a-justified-use-of|work=Border Fact Check|publisher=Washington Office on Latin America|accessdate=October 23, 2012}}</ref> In September 2015, Swartz was indicted on the charge of second-degree murder.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. Border Patrol agent indicted for murder over 2012 shooting|url=https://news.yahoo.com/u-border-patrol-agent-indicted-murder-over-2012-020116988.html |date=September 25, 2015|publisher=Reuters|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305141650/http://news.yahoo.com/u-border-patrol-agent-indicted-murder-over-2012-020116988.html|archivedate=March 5, 2016}}</ref>
===Incidents involving use of tear gas and pepper spray=== On November 25, 2013, the San Diego Tribune reported that 100 migrants who tried to cross the border in the to illegally cross the border near the San Ysidro port were pepper-sprayed and tear-gassed after throwing bottles and rocks at border patrol agents.<ref>https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-border-patrol-rock-throwing-san-ysidro-2013nov25-story,amp.html?__twitter_impression=true</ref> A similar incident was reported in November 2018.<ref>https://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2018/11/26/beto-orourke-condemns-use-tear-gas-migrants-border-including-children</ref>
===Allegations of abuse===
Various civil society and human rights organizations have alleged that abuses of migrants by Border Patrol agents occur frequently:
*Between 2010 and 2011 alleged excessive use of force by Border Patrol and Field Operations agents led to the death of six Mexican citizens. A PBS report, ''Crossing the Line'', released in July 2012, profiled the case of Hernández-Rojas who died after being beaten and while in custody of the USBP, ICE, and CBP in May 2010.<ref name="Meyer" /><ref name="DOJ_2015" /> In 2012, in a letter to President Obama posted on the website of the Washington Office on Latin America, 118 civil society organizations criticized the Border Patrol for failing to thoroughly investigate the incident and stated that the Border Patrol "is operating with very little transparency and virtual impunity, especially in the southern border region where Border Patrol and other CBP agents regularly violate the human and civil rights of those who call the border region home."<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. Organizations Urge President Obama to Address Border Patrol Abuses |url=http://www.wola.org/news/us_organizations_send_letter_to_president_obama_on_customs_and_border_protection_abuses|publisher=Washington Office on Latin America|accessdate=August 23, 2012|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108064131/http://www.wola.org/news/us_organizations_send_letter_to_president_obama_on_customs_and_border_protection_abuses|archivedate=November 8, 2012}}</ref> *From 2008–2011, the Arizona organization [[No More Deaths]] interviewed nearly 13,000 migrants who had been in Border Patrol custody, in the Arizona border towns of Naco, Nogales, and Agua Prieta. Their report, ''A Culture of Cruelty'', documents alleged abuses including denial of or insufficient water and food; failure to provide medical treatment; verbal, physical and psychological abuse; separation of family members and dangerous repatriation practices. In February 2012, Border Patrol Chief Michael Fisher stated in congressional testimony that the Border Patrol takes allegations of abuse seriously.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fisher|first=Michael |title=Testimony of Chief Michael Fisher |url=http://www.micevhill.com/attachments/immigration_documents/hosted_documents/112th_congress/TranscriptOfHouseAppropriationsSubcommitteeHearingOnFY13CBPBudgetRequest.pdf|work=Transcript of House Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security Hearing on the Proposed Fiscal 2013 Appropriations for the U.S. Customs and Border Protection|publisher=House Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security|accessdate=August 23, 2012|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412145047/http://www.micevhill.com/attachments/immigration_documents/hosted_documents/112th_congress/TranscriptOfHouseAppropriationsSubcommitteeHearingOnFY13CBPBudgetRequest.pdf|archivedate=April 12, 2013}}</ref> However, No More Deaths testified before the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights in March 2012 and stated that in spite of raising their concerns for several years, "the agency has taken the position that such abuses simply do not occur."<ref name="Meyer"/> *There are allegations of abuse by the United States Border Patrol such as the ones reported by Jesus A. Trevino, that concludes in an article published in the ''Houston Journal of International Law'' (2006) with a request to create an independent review commission to oversee the actions of the Border Patrol, and that creating such review board will make the American public aware of the "serious problem of abuse that exists at the border by making this review process public" and that "illegal immigrants deserve the same constitutionally-mandated humane treatment of citizens and legal residents".<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.hjil.org/ArticleFiles/21_1_10.pdf|title=Border violence against illegal immigrants and the need to change the border patrol's current complaint review process|author=Jesus A. Trevino|journal=Houston Journal of International Law|year=1998|volume=21 |issue=1|pages=85–114|issn=0194-1879|accessdate=June 1, 2009|format=PDF|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726152251/http://www.hjil.org/ArticleFiles/21_1_10.pdf|archivedate=July 26, 2011}}</ref>
*In 1998, [[Amnesty International]] investigated allegations of ill-treatment and brutality by officers of the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]], and particularly the Border Patrol. Their report said they found indications of [[human rights]] violations during 1996, 1997 and early 1998.<ref>{{Cite journal|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|date=May 19, 1998 |url=http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/engAMR510031998|title=United States of America: Human rights concerns in the border region with Mexico|accessdate=June 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021020708/http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/engAMR510031998 |archivedate=October 21, 2007}}</ref> *An article in ''Social Justice'' by Michael Huspek, Leticia Jimenez, Roberto Martinez (1998) cites that in December 1997, John Case, head of the INS Office of Internal Audit, announced at a press conference that public complaints to the INS had risen 29% from 1996, with the "vast majority" of complaints emanating from the southwest border region, but that of the 2,300 cases, the 243 cases of serious allegations of abuse were down in 1997. These serious cases are considered to be distinct from less serious complaints, such as "verbal abuse, discrimination, extended detention without cause."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huspek|first=Michael|author2=Roberto Martinez|author3=Leticia Jimenez|title=Violations of human and civil rights on the U.S.-Mexico border, 1995 to 1997: a report |journal=Social Justice|format=Reprint|volume=25|issue=2|year=1998|issn=1043-1578 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3427/is_n2_v25/ai_n28711340/|accessdate=June 1, 2009}}<p>The data compiled in this report suggest that law enforcement in the southwest region of the United States may be verging on lawlessness. This statement receives fuller support from announcements emanating from the INS. In December 1997, John Chase, head of the INS Office of Internal Audit, announced at a press conference that public complaints to the INS had risen 29% from 1996, with the "vast majority" of complaints emanating from the southwest border region. Over 2,300 complaints were filed in 1997 as opposed to the 1,813 complaints filed in 1996. Another 400 reports of "minor misconduct" were placed in a new category. Chase was quick to emphasize, however, that the 243 "serious" allegations of abuse and use of excessive force that could warrant criminal prosecution were down in 1997, as compared with the 328 in 1996. These "serious" cases are considered to be distinct from less serious complaints, such as "verbal abuse, discrimination, extended detention without cause.</ref>
===Corruption=== Incidences of corruption in the U.S. Border Patrol include: *Pablo Sergio Barry, an agent charged with one count of harboring an illegal alien (8 U.S.C. § 1324),<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/8/1324 8 USC § 1324 – Bringing in and harboring certain aliens | Title 8 – Aliens and Nationality | U.S. Code | LII / Legal Information Institute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405170716/https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/8/1324 |date=April 5, 2017 }}. Law.cornell.edu. Retrieved on July 23, 2013.</ref> three counts of false statements, and two counts of making a false document.<ref{{cite news|title=Border agent accused of hiding an illegal entrant|url=http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/border/81082.php|newspaper=Arizona Daily Star|date=2005-06-23|accessdate=2009-06-01|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221172057/http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/border/81082.php|archivedate=2007-12-21}}</ref> He pleaded guilty.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Border agent pleads guilty to harboring illegal entrant |url=http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/border/94491.php|newspaper=Arizona Daily Star|date=September 22, 2005|accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221172102/http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/border/94491.php|archivedate=December 21, 2007}}</ref> *Christopher E. Bernis, an agent indicted on a charge of harboring an illegal alien for nine months while employed as a U.S. Border Patrol Agent.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{Cite news|title=U.S. border agent indicted |url=http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/border/65117.php |newspaper=Arizona Daily Star|date=March 11, 2005|accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221172052/http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/border/65117.php|archivedate=December 21, 2007}}</ref> *Jose De Jesus Ruiz, an agent whose [[girlfriend]] was an illegal alien, he was put on administrative leave pending an investigation.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> *Oscar Antonio Ortiz, an illegal alien<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|title=Border agent said to also be smuggler |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/tijuana/20050805-9999-7m5agent.htm |date=August 5, 2005 |work=SignOnSanDiego.com |publisher=Union-Tribune Publishing |accessdate=June 1, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> who used a fake [[birth certificate]] to get into the Border Patrol admitted to smuggling more than 100 illegal aliens into the U.S., some of them in his government truck,<ref>{{Cite news|title=Border agent gets 5 years for smuggling|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/28/AR2006072800910.html|date=July 28, 2006|author=Spagat, Elliot|newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=June 1, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331083202/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/28/AR2006072800910.html|archivedate=March 31, 2012}}</ref> and was helping to smuggle illegal aliens and charged with conspiring with another agent to smuggle aliens. *An unidentified patrol agent who was recorded on a wire tap stating that he helped to smuggle 30 to 50 aliens at a time.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==National Border Patrol Council== National Border Patrol Council (NBPC) is the [[labor union]] which represents over 17,000 Border Patrol agents and support staff. The NBPC was founded on November 1, 1965, and its parent organization is the [[American Federation of Government Employees]], [[AFL-CIO]]. The NBPC's executive committee is staffed by current and retired Border Patrol agents and, along with its constituent locals, employs a staff of a dozen attorneys and field representatives. The NBPC is associated with the Peace Officer Research Association of California Legal Defense Fund|California's Legal Defense Fund.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbpc.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=25&Itemid=42|title=About NBPC|date=August 14, 2008|publisher=National Border Patrol Council |accessdate=June 1, 2009}}</ref>
==Border Patrol Foundation== The Border Patrol Foundation was founded in 2009 to assist the survivors of agents killed in the line of duty. The foundation provides financial support to immediate family members, peer family support, and a scholarship to eligible children. The foundation recognizes community leaders who have supported the families of fallen agents, and supports programs to improve awareness of the risks faced by agents.<ref>{{cite web|title=Border Patrol Foundation|publisher=Border Patrol Foundation|year=2013 |url=http://borderpatrolfoundation.org/|deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531055809/http://borderpatrolfoundation.org/|archivedate=May 31, 2013}}</ref>
